title: Exploring The Famous NIYAAZ BELGAUM BIRYANI! Chicken & Mutton Biryani Making Revealed!
description:
#niyaazbiryani #belagavi #biryanimaking

belgaum’s most famous biryani, popular biryani restaurant in belgaum, niyaaz biryani belgaum, chicken biryani, mutton biryani, biryani making, belagavi, belgaum, belagavi biryani, niyaz belgaum biryani, niyaaz hotel belgaum biryani recipe, north karnataka food tour, belgaum food trail, belgaum food trail, belgaum food tour

How do biryanis become iconic? Well, most begin as tentative experiments and over a period of time endear themselves to the palate of the locals. So much so that the denizens of the place become vocal ambassadors for the biryani. And when it comes to Belagavi (Belgaum), the Niyaaz biryani is one such icon. Made in the kacchi akhni style, in which semi-cooked rice is layered over twice-marinated meat and cooked on dum, the Niyaaz biryani is subtle in its character, owing to a unique blend of spices, and the light fragrance of a short-grain locally grown rice that is used in combination with the more typical long grain basmati rice. What began as a family’s endeavour to create a unique biryani 30 years ago is now unarguably one of Belagavi’s most popular dishes. In this episode, I drive to Belgaum to meet co-owner, Niyaaz Abdussalam Saudagar, and explore in depth the making of both the chicken and mutton biryani, before proceeding to make a meal of these distinct Belagavi culinary signatures. Hope you enjoy this one; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

Rs. 180
9/10

It is a well-known fact that Pavithra Idli Hotel on NH 48 in Khyatasandra, just outside Tumakuru is famous for the thatte idli that they have been dishing out for 36 years now. But what I found most interesting is the meticulous attention to detail of the owner, Mr. Udaykumar, he actually refers to himself as the third owner, the first two, he says, are his customers and employees, in his well-planned and spacious kitchen, that is more than twice the size of the dining area, and could perhaps outrival most traditional kitchens on the highways of India. So confident is he about his back areas that he offers willing customers a tour without hesitation. It is no wonder then that the fare served here - the thatte idli, and also a scrumptious mini benne masala dosae that I wasn't expecting - has swarms of fans for whom a stop at Pavithra Idli is a must when on the road here.

title: Her Culinary Tribute To Her Late Husband! AGRAANE KITCHEN Bengaluru | Street Food Of Hubli
description:
hubli street food in bangalore, agraane kitchen, lady entrepreneur, small business, vegetarian, durgadbail girmit, girmit, mirchi, bun bonda, bun mirchi, avalakki usalli, cut mirchi, bangalore street food, veerabhadra nagar, banashankari, bengaluru, bangalore

In happier times, Bhagya Kulkarni’s conversations with her husband, noted television personality, Sanjeev Kulkarni, often revolved around bringing the street food of Hubballi, their hometown to Bengaluru. Their trips back home always included tasting forays to the eateries of Durgadbail and incessant recipe experimentations to perfect the robust masalas of Hubli street fare. When he fell ill, she set up a small business catering Uttara Karnataka meals out of their home in South Bengaluru to support the family. Unfortunately, he passed on, but Bhagya Kulkarni was determined to fulfil their dream, and thus was born Agraane Kitchen, a tiny shop that serves up the Durgadbail girmit, mirchi, avalakki usli, bun bonda, cut mirchi, etc., in addition to typical breakfast offerings and an austere but wholesome jowar rotti meal during lunch. I visit them on a rainy evening to savour the spicy, snacky street fare that I missed on my recent Hubli expedition, and to also support this enterprise that in a manner of speaking, is this brave lady’s culinary tribute to her late husband. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: Visit SUVARNA MANDIR, Hubli's Oldest Restaurant For Tasty Misal, Madike Kalu & A Slice Of History!
description:
#suvarnamandir #hubballi #oldestrestaurant

popular vegetarian restaurant in hubli, oldest restaurant in hubli, suvarna mandir, breakfast, tiffin, puri bhaaji, misal, madke kaalu, hubli, hubbali, north karnataka food tour, hubli food trail, hubli food tour, hubli food veg, hubli food, family run, durgadbail market, durgadbail hubli

Established in 1940, Suvarna Mandir is perhaps Hubballi’s oldest restaurant, if not the oldest. Located amidst the hustle and bustle of Durgadbail market, it’s quite easy to miss the tiny doorway that opens into a courtyard setting in an ancient home from nearly a century ago. Looked after by third generation custodian Mr. Prakash Bhatt, when asked if he was the owner, replied that he was merely taking care of the space like his grandfather and father had before him, this eatery’s charming old school disposition extends to the fare that is served here. Misal, aloo bonda, poori bhaji, madke kaalu, etc. typical Hubli vegetarian breakfast snack fare, but one that is steeped in nostalgia for the locals, and reminiscent of old-fashioned goodness if you happen to be a visitor like me. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: This Home Serves Hubballi’s Most Popular Konkani Style Seafood Meals! ONLY FISH
description:
#onlyfish #seafood #hubli 

popular seafood restaurant in hubli, only fish, family run, home restaurant, seafood thaali, surmai thali, prawn fry, bolanjir fry, anchovy, fresh seafood, only fish hubli, north karnataka food tour, hubli food trail, hubli food tour, seafood in hubli

In 2001, Mrs. Radha Bhat began a small eatery on the terrace of her home in Vidya Nagar, Hubballi to serve simple, fresh fare to students and working professionals in the neighbourhood who were yearning for home cooked meals. Slowly, but surely, the reputation of her Konkani seafood preparations, the fish sourced from the coastal town of Honnavar, began to travel, attracting not just those in the area but also visitors from far flung cities and towns in North Karnataka. Staffed only by women barring Mrs. Bhatt’s husband and son, Only Fish is a definite must-visit when in the city for its Konkani homestyle seafood fare served at extremely economical prices, as I discovered one rainy evening. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: Tasty, Rustic JOLADA ROTTI Veg Meal At BASAVESHWAR KHANAVALI, Hubli | Rotti Making Secret Revealed!
description:
#hubballi #basaveshwarkhanavali #joladarotti

original north karnataka restaurant from dharwad, hubli, hubballi, north karnataka, jollada rotti meals, jowar rotti, maddike kaalu, moth beans, badanekayi ennegayi, eggplant, donne menasinakai, gurelu, shenga, chutney, jhunka, obbatu, hollige, north karnataka food tour, hubli food trail, hubli food tour, hubli food veg, hubli food, family run

The fertile black soil of North Karnataka yields a rich bounty of vegetables and grain, and this delicious, fresh produce is best experienced in a traditional Jolada Rotti (jowar rotti) vegetarian meal at a khanavali (eating house) in the region. And the most popular jolada rotti oota seems to be the one served at Basaveshwar Khanavali, a string of vegetarian eateries in Dharwad, Hubballi and now, Bengaluru, that date back to 1963. We visited their main branch at Chennamma Circle in Hubballi, where we met the Ganachari family that is committed to serving sumptuous North Karnataka meals, and also discovered an interesting technique that makes their jolada rotti special. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

title: When In Hubballi, You Must Eat At GURUDATTA BHAVAN! Hubli’s Most Popular Restaurant!
description:
#hubli #gurudattabhavan #poorikurma

popular vegetarian restaurant in hubli, breakfast, lunch, tiffin, puri kurma, idli vada, upppittu, upma, vegetable palav, hubli, hubbali, north karnataka food tour, hubli food trail, hubli food tour, hubli food veg, hubli food, family run
 
When Mr Vasudev Shetty moved from Mangalore to Hubli to begin Gurudatta Bhavan in 1958, he may not have imagined that in times to come his eatery would become one of the most popular food destinations in this bustling commercial hub. Be it breakfast, lunch or dinner, Gurudatta Bhavan seems to draw in the denizens of Hubballi in numbers for its tasty fare that blends Mangalorean culinary style with influences of the land. I pop in for breakfast one morning to savour their sought-after puri kurma amongst other dishes, and also meet the family behind this 63-year-old restaurant. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay strong and safe. Happy eating!

title: Bengaluru’s Favourite KARNATAKA BHEL HOUSE Full Menu Tasting! Satisfying Chaat Cravings Since 1975!
description:
#chaats #chaatmaking #bangalore

chaat in bangalore, bangalore’s very popular chaat shop, karnataka bhel house, kbh, karnataka bhel house chamrajpet, masala puri, sev puri, bhel puri, dahi puri, paani puri, evening snacks, street food, bengaluru, bangalore street food, traditional, family run, chaat recipe, chaat making

Every city has its distinctive chaat style, so does Bengaluru, including its very unique masala puri that is a hit with folks here. And a popular chaat destination is Karnataka Bhel House, which began as one of the earliest stores unlike food carts way back in 1975. Founded by Mr Prabhulinga Linga Dev who converted his provision store in Chamrajpet to a chaat shop on the advice of a friend who had just returned from plying the trade in Mumbai, KBH, as it is popularly known, may have branched out into spiffy operations across multiple outlets today. However, it is the consistency of the chaats here, we are told by its fans, thanks to the owning family’s focus on sourcing the best ingredients, for instance, the peas that go into the masala come from the US to ensure the same taste year-round, whilst all components and condiments that go into the chaat are produced in their central kitchen, that has made Karnataka Bhel House a popular chaat destination. I visit the flagship Chamrajpet store to take a close look at this bustling operation, and also savour everything on the menu! Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: This Family Is Serving Must-Try SAVAJI Mutton Meals At Their Home In HUBLI! NAKOD SAVAJI KHANAVALI
description:
#hubli #savajimutton #muttonthali

popular savaji meal, savaji mutton, nakod savaji khanavali, savaji mutton curry, mutton thaali, mutton fry, mutton kheema, mutton chops, saoji mutton, mutton liver, lunch, butter market, durgadbail, hubli, hubbali, north karnataka food tour, hubli food trail, hubli food tour, hubli food non veg, hubli saoji food, family run, nakod savaji

If you are a meat lover, partaking of a traditional Savaji mutton meal is a must when in Hubli. Served in traditional homes of the Savaji community, almost hidden away in tiny bylanes of the city, the dishes are cooked by the women of the house and served exclusively by the menfolk. In this episode, we venture out to Nakod Savaji Khanavali in Durgadbail, and are rewarded with a delicious mutton meal, notwithstanding the seemingly brusque welcome and service ritual that only goes to reinforce the fact that it is all about the food here! Whilst at the eatery, we also take a peek into the kitchen to meet three generations of the Nakod family, including the women folk who cook the sheep-based fare to recipes that have been handed down through generations. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

description:
#davanagere #bennedosa #srigurukottureshwara

popular davanagere benne dosae shop, sri guru kottureshwara butter dosa hotel, bapuji dental college, medical college road, davanagere, sri guru kottureshwara davangere butter dosa, butter dosa, benne dose, benne dosa, khaali dosa, khaali dose, north karnataka food tour, davanagere street food, davanagere food trail, street food in davanagere benne dosa recipe, davangere benne dosa recipe hotel style, benne dosa davangere, traditional, family run

Whilst no one knows exactly how many benne (butter) dosae eateries exist in Davanagere, some say over a hundred and fifty, also earning for this city, the moniker, ‘Benne Nagari’, most would agree that it is Sri Guru Kottureshwara Butter Dosa Hotel that seems to have put this scrumptious, fluffy, butter-laden, wood-fire roasted popular offering on the world map. Located strategically in a neighbourhood teeming with medical and engineering colleges, it was only a matter of time before the students for whom the dosae served here was daily sustenance, passed out and went across India and all over the globe evangelising the delicious virtues of the fare on offer at Sri Guru Kottureshwara. On a recent ‘gourmet on the road’ expedition, I stopped by this iconic 37-year-old eatery to meet the family and explore what makes the Davanegere Benne Dosae  “world famous”! Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Davanagere Benne Dosae
Rs. 80 (usd 1.1) for two dosae
9.5/10

Khaali Dosae
Rs. 40 (usd 0.5) for three dosae
8/10

ADDRESS -  Sri Guru Kottureshwara Butter Dosa Hotel, Medical College Rd, MCC B Block, Kuvempu Nagar, Davanagere, Karnataka 577004; tel: +91 63625 25615; Location tag: https://goo.gl/maps/FRZedi1Dkt6SgysV6
TIMINGS: 730am to 930pm
Note: Dining here may involve a short wait especially during peak hours.

title: Tasting Davanagere’s Most Popular MIRCHI MANDAKKI At SUBBANNA MIRCHI MASALA!
description:
#davanagere #mirchimandakki #streetfood

popular davanagere snack, subanna mandakki mirchi, subbanna mirchi masala, north karnataka food tour, davanagere street food, davanagere mirchi mandakki, davanagere food trail, street food in davanagere, mandakki, mirchi, oggarane mandakki, ambode, mirchi making, mirchi bajji, recipe, traditional, family run

Hi folks, kicking off our North Karnataka series with this short and spicy episode that we filmed impromptu enroute to Hubli. Stopping at Davanagere, a city popularly known as Benne Nagari (the land of butter) to taste an iconic benne dosae, we were told that a visit here would be considered incomplete without tasting the crowd-pleasing evening snack of mirchi mandakki. Especially the one dished out at Subbanna Mirchi Masala, a tiny shop that has stood the test of time for over seven decades now. I catch up with the locals, and also the friendly owners, brothers, Subbanna and Srikanth, whose grandfather began the Subbanna mirchi mandakki tradition! Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

Rs. 20 
9/10

title: MANGALORE IN BANGALORE | Fresh Affordable Seafood Truck By Kundapur Engineers Who Love Fish!
description:
#seafood #foodtruck #bangalore

seafood truck offering huge variety of seafood, mangalore in bangalore, seafood truck, affordable, fresh seafood, fish curry, prawn ghee roast, fish fry, chicken curry, upkoli, oyster sukka, mackerel, bangude, anjal, seer, kane, lady fish, mud crabs, sea prawns, street food, rajarajeshwari nagar, rr nagar, seafood in bangalore, bengaluru, bangalore street food, bangalore food truck, young enterprise, local enterprise

Childhood friends, Koushik, Sachin and Sanketh, grew up in Kundapur, fascinated by the teeming variety of marine produce brought in by boats to the fishing ports of South Canara. The boys found themselves pursuing engineering degrees in Bengaluru, yet dreaming of seafood. Upon completing their studies, the engineers returned to Kundapur, built a food truck, roped in a village cook, before driving back to Bengaluru to launch their ‘Mangalore in Bangalore’ sea food enterprise. I visit them on a rainy evening for an interesting chat, and return mighty impressed with the marine spread on offer, the un-compromised rustic flavour of most of the dishes that I taste, and their commitment to offering fresh seafood at honest prices. If Dakshina Kannada coastal fare is your thing, or you are a seafood lover, do look up this young but delicious venture. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating.

title: Tasting MRS. MUTHULAKSHMI’s Gobi Manchuri | Amazing CHITRADURGA MIRCHI MANDAKKI Viewer Response
description:
#streetfood #reaction #bangalore

street food in bengaluru, chitradurga street food, chitradurga mirchi mandakki centre, mandakki oggarane, girmit masala, muthulakshmi gobi, aunty gobi, gobi manchuri, aunty gobi manchurian, street food, inspiring story, jp nagar, bangalore, bengaluru, inspiring story, family enterprise, support small business

Whilst we receive many messages, pictures, videos and comments on how an eatery is faring post a Gourmet On the Road episode, we rarely ever return immediately after the video is aired. However, we learnt that Chitradurga Mirchi Mandakki, an inspiring street food story, was overwhelmed with customers after our video, so I decided to venture out to see this response for myself and to also encourage the family behind this enterprise. I got to interact with many of our viewers, and along the way also met another inspiring street food vendor, Mrs. Muthulakshmi, who cajoled me into tasting her crunchy gobi manchuri. Hope you enjoy this off-the-cuff episode. Take care, stay safe and strong Happy eating!


Kripal Amanna,

title: ARALIMARA PANI POORI | This Famous, Must-Try BENGALURU CHAAT Shop’s Legacy Goes Back To 1950!
description:
#chaats #chaatmaking #bangalore

chaat in bangalore, bangalore’s very popular chaat shop in chamrajpet, aralimara pani poori, aralimara panipuri chamrajpet, masala poori, sev poori, bhel poori, dahi poori, paani poori, evening snacks, street food, bengaluru, bangalore street food, traditional, family run, chaat recipe, chaat making

Orphaned at a young age and in search of a livelihood, Huchappa migrated from his village to Bengaluru in 1950. He found employment with UP Brahmins who were dispensing paani poori from streetside carts. Having learnt the trade, he struck out on his own with a pushcart in Nagarathpet in 1950, infusing North Indian style chaats with local flavours. His son, Kumar continues the tradition under the shade of a temple peepal tree, which also gives his very popular chaat shop its name, Arali Mara, peepal tree in Kannada. In this chatpata episode, I taste most of the chaats on offer here. Hope you enjoy this one; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: Tasting Bengaluru’s Favourite Hot & Spicy Egg Rice At SNEHAJEEVI GOWDARA ADDA EGGRICE! Egg Masala
description:
#eggs #friedrice #bangalore

bangalore’s most popular egg rice, snehajeevi gowdara adda egg rice, egg fried rice, malleshwaram egg rice, street food, eggs, fried rice, egg masala, egg rice recipe, small business, family run, neighbourhood eatery, malleshwaram

Bengaluru loves its egg rice, a heavily indigenised variation of the fried rice fortified with an amalgam of punchy spices and fresh ingredients to cater to local palates. Whilst one will find a popular egg rice cart in almost every neighbourhood, there is perhaps none as popular as Snehajeevi Gowdara Adda Egg Rice, that thumps out enormous quantities to queues of patrons who wait patiently for the hot, spicy rice and other egg-y creations at this shop, ironically, located in the predominantly vegetarian neighbourhood of Malleshwaram. I dropped in one afternoon to take a closer look at this tasty creation and chat with the owner, Kumar Gowda, who began making egg rice in his pushcart 18 years ago when he was forced to give up the tender coconut trade. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

Egg Rice 
Rs. 70 (usd 0.9)
8/10

Egg Masala 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
8/10

8.5/10 when tasted in combination.

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 9am to 10pm; 11am to 10pm on Sundays

title: Bengaluru’s Most Popular MYSORE PAK, DUMROTE | Original SRI VENKATESHWARA SWEETMEAT STALL 100 Years!
description:
#mysorepak #dumrot #bangalore

bangalore’s most popular mysore pak, original sri venkateshwara sweetmeat stall, sweet shop in balepet, bangalore, mysore pak, dumrote, pure ghee sweets, traditional mithai, family run 

When it comes to the tuppada (ghee) Mysore Pak in Bengaluru, all roads lead to the original, Sri Venkateshwara Sweetmeat Stall in Balepet, an establishment with a legacy that spans over a century. After making a beginning in Chikkaballapur, the patriarch VA Venkatachalapathy Setty migrated to Bengaluru in 1952 to introduce the denizens of this city to his style of Mysore Pak, lush with ghee, and another equally popular invention, the Dumrote, a slow-baked crusty halwa made of ash gourd that takes the better part of a day to prepare. I catch up with the second, third and fourth generation of this iconic sweetmeat shop, and delve into the making of the Mysore Pak and Dumrote. Needless to say, I only leave after tasting these much sought-after Bengaluru delicacies. Hope you enjoy this unabashedly decadent mithai episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: SHINE SHETTY’s New GALLI KITCHEN Brings Flavours of Manguluru To Bengaluru! Goli Baje, Buns & More
description:
#shineshetty #mangaloreanfood #bangalore 

galli kitchen, shine shetty, popular food stall run by kannada actor shine shetty, big boss kannada winner, inspirational story, vegetarian, mangalorean food, mangalorean snacks, mangalore buns, goli baje, mangalore baji, menthya dosa, wheat halbai, mangalore snacks, rajarajeshwari nagar, rr nagar , south bangalore, bangalore

Begun as a means of survival when this actor was going through a difficult phase in his career, Shine Shetty’s food venture is one that inspires hope. After his food truck success, his new streetside stall, Galli Kitchen Rajarajeshwari Nagar, celebrates his South Canara heritage in a range of vegetarian delicacies that will warm the cockles of any Mangalorean’s heart! Prepared with family recipes, the scrumptious Mangalore buns and goli baje served steaming hot, menthya dose with lashings of tuppa and bella kai, and godhi halbai amongst other dishes, are the sort that make the trek to this suburb of South Bengaluru well worth the effort, as I discovered during an evening with Shine and his family. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong.

A café set in a home, Eat Repeat is IT professionals turned entrepreneurs, Kannan and Sangeetha’s ode to their Iyengar heritage. Made to authentic traditions, the vegetarian dishes here are devoid of onion and garlic, but pack loads of flavour, as I discovered in the Puliyogare, Chakkara Pongal and some of the other tiffin items that I tasted. The fare is simple yet wholesome, made and served with the sort of love, conversation and attention that one would expect as a guest in someone’s home. When members of the Subbanna family from Lakkondahalli, a village near Hoskote, settled in Bengaluru, they kept their connection to their land alive in the food that was served at home. Wanting to share their rustic cuisine with Bengaluru, they set up Naati Sogadu in Sahakar Nagar, North Bengaluru, a restaurant that quickly became popular for its homestyle non vegetarian fare, cooked almost entirely by the family. In this episode, I return to Naati Sogadu, post lockdown, to meet and support the Subbanna family and also savour dishes that I had not tasted during my first visit. title: Inspiring Street Food Story! Engineering Student Supports Family! CHITRADURGA MIRCHI MANDAKKI CENTRE
description:
#girmit #bajji #bangalore

chitradurga street food, chitradurga mirchi mandakki centre, mandakki oggarane, girmit masala, operation bajji, chitradurga mirchi, chilli, capsicum bajji, onion bajji, street food, inspiring story, jp nagar, bangalore, bengaluru, inspiring story, family enterprise, support small business

It would be an understatement to say that current times have been especially tough for street food vendors, most who manage to earn barely enough for the day without much of a safety net to fall back upon. Against this backdrop, we were moved to hear of the struggles of a young engineering student who almost single handedly, with his mother, embarked upon a street cart venture to rescue his father and family from a crippling financial setback. And in the course of doing so, reconnected his father with a delicious North Karnataka snack tradition. In this street food episode, I stop by at Chitradurga Girmit Mandakki Centre to meet Ullas Basavaraju and his father, and also taste the Chitradurga mirchi in a scrumptiously delicious spicy avatar, some girmit mandakki masala and a rather intriguingly named ‘operation bajji’! Hope you enjoy this inspiring story; please spare a moment for eateries like these, and do your best to support them. Take care; stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: This Malleswaram Family Makes Pure Milk Old-Fashioned Ice Cream! Must-Try AMRITH ICECREAMS Bengaluru
description:
#vegetarian #icecream #bangalore

amrith ice creams, handmade, pure milk ice cream, kesar, manoranjini, malai kulfi, butterscotch, fig and honey, coffee, chocolate chip, vanilla, litchi with apricot, ice cream, malleswaram, bangalore, bengaluru, family enterprise

In a quiet bylane of Malleshwaram, sits a family-run enterprise that has been churning homemade ice creams the good old-fashioned way for nearly three decades using pure milk and milk fats, and devoid of any preservatives. It owes its origin to the late Mr. MN Sarathy, who after extensive training in ice cream making in Europe, set up this artisan ice cream parlour in his home nearly three decades ago. His family continues in his footsteps, strictly adhering to time-honoured recipes and methods, serving what is perhaps Bengaluru’s best old-fashioned ice cream. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: Burgers WIth A Tasty Twist! BOSS BURGERS | Piri Piri Chicken, Guacamole Bean, Juicy Mutton, Quinoa
description:
#burgers #takeaway #bangalore

takeaway burgers, best burgers, bangalore, burger trail, guacamole black bean burger, quinoa vegetable burger, chicken piri piri burger, mutton burger, chicken tikka burger, bengaluru

I had never been a fan of burgers in takeaway mode. The buns usually suffer the ill effects of the journey, arriving limp and soggy, with the filling inadvertently reorganised depending on how bumpy the ride has been from the kitchen to your home. But we were blown away by the near pristine condition in which this extravagant order of burgers arrived, packed in sturdy cartons equipped with air vents to dissipate moisture. Packaging aside, the flavour and texture combinations too are the sort that work well to please most palates. As we discovered in this leisurely amble through some of Boss Burger’s most popular offerings, from a spicy chicken piri to desi chicken tikka, crunchy quinoa and root veggies to guacamole black bean and a loaded juicy mutton version that mimicked the smoky character of seekh kebab. Hope you enjoy this burger extravaganza; take care, stay safe and strong. Happy eating!

title: Bengaluru’s Most Popular Masala Dosas! CTR vs. MTR vs. VIDYARTHI BHAVAN!
description:
#ctr #mtr #vidyarthibhavan 

most popular masala dosas in bangalore, masala dosae, tiffin, ctr, mtr, mavalli tiffin rooms, lalbagh, vidyarthi bhavan, basavanagudi, bengaluru, bangalore

When it comes to the ubiquitous masala dosae here in Bengaluru, everyone has an opinion, actually many opinions, and clear favourites. Stuck at home during the recent lockdown, I couldn’t help but reminisce tasting three of Bengaluru’s most popular versions, and put together a special compilation for you, highlights of the CTR, MTR (Mavalli Tiffin Room, Lalbagh) and Vidyarthi Bhavan masala dosae from Gourmet On The Road.

Hope you enjoy this short and scrumptious bonus video; take care, stay safe and happy eating! 

CTR Benne Masala Dosa
This butter-drenched gold-hued dose is blessed with the perfect gentle crackle. On the palate, one tastes the lushness of the homemade butter that envelopes every bite of the dose, the palya and the chutney with its delicious veil. If you need one reason to visit CTR, this would be it.
Rs. 57 (usd 0.8)
10/10

MTR MASALA DOSA
The dosa here is iconic and never disappoints. Made with a blend of three rice varieties, including two red rice varieties that lend a toasty colour tone, the dose is crisp outside and soft within. The palya is seasoned just right. 
Rs. 90 (usd 1.3)
10

Vidyarthi Bhavan Masala Dosa
If you need one reason to visit Vidyarthji Bhavan, this would be it. A dose that’s crisp and lacey in parts, soft and fluffy in others, and hides within its single fold a creamy potato palya. The chutney is spicy and vivacious, a bold complement to the gentle flavours of the dose and palya.
Rs. 53 (usd 0.7) 
10/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

title: Support This Couple Who Gave Up Corporate Jobs To Serve "Pure & Traditional" BANGALORE TIFFINS!
description:
#vegetarian #breakfast #bengaluru

bangalore tiffins, south indian eatery, north bengaluru, bangalore, jakkur, bangalore tiffins, pudi idli, thatte idli, benne idli, masala dosa, dose, ragi rotti, akki rotti, rakki rotti, kesari baath, support takeaway, small business, inspiration story, young food entrepreneurs, bengaluru

Nagajyothi and her husband Manish Eswar gave up successful careers in the corporate world to set up Bangalore Tiffins, a modest eatery in Jakkur, North Bengaluru, where they serve traditional vegetarian tiffin fare made to their family recipes. Their offering is endearing in its simplicity, keeping in line with this young couple’s philosophy of serving “food that is pure and devoid of artificial additives, like soda, colours and taste enhancers.” Notwithstanding the current situation, and many setbacks along the way, including one where they lost all their cooks, thereby compelling Nagajyothi to take charge of the kitchen, Bangalore Tiffins holds promise in building for itself a solid reputation on the basis of its food, especially dishes like the pudi idli and masala dosa that I tasted on this breakfast outing. Hope you enjoy this episode enough to support neighbourhood eateries like these; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Over a year and a half ago, I visited Mangala Vilas, a 60plus year old eatery in Salem to explore the non vegetarian flavours of Konganadu, a unique cuisine, at the heart of which is a dark roasted masala of 15 or 16 spices. Needless to say, it was a meal quite interesting, especially having interacted with the skilled kitchen hands in Salem’s oldest non-vegetarian restaurant perhaps. The family behind Mangala Vilas have recently opened an outpost here in Namma Bengaluru, and I lost no time in ordering a big takeaway of their iconic dishes like the naatu kozhi leg roast, pichi potta fry, mutton chukka, kothu parotta, egg labba, among others. To many of us, a common food memory growing up was Maggi, the quintessential quick snack, and also a hunger saviour when one was cramming for exams late into the night! It had been a while since I tasted some, when I heard of this quaint six-seater eatery in Jayanagar, Bengaluru, that is redefining this fondly-remembered comfort food in the many varieties they dish out. From incorporating exotic fresh ingredients like basil and mushrooms to spicing it up with the stinging bite of fresh habanero pepper and mollycoddling it in cheese, this is the sort of Maggi that seems to have grown beyond its two-minute tagline! Much like the current palate of its patrons of yesteryear. 

Head to The Blue Wagon Kitchen or order in to savour the exciting avatars of your erstwhile two-minute sustenance! Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

title: Tasting Must-Try GREEN MASALA IDLI & More At 70-Year-Old NEW KRISHNA BHAVAN | Green Masala Recipe
description:

popular vegetarian eatery, new krishna bhavan, green masala idli, green masala idli recipe, madurai garam idli, button idli, tomato omelette jowar dosa, mysore pak, badam halwa, nkb, malleswaram, bengaluru, support local eateries, takeaway, dine in, south canara cuisine 

Not many know this interesting trivia about New Krishna Bhavan, Malleswaram, that until the recent lockdown this restaurant had not closed its doors even for a single day ever since they opened for business in 1954! Quite in contrast to the popularity of this vegetarian eatery. 
NKB, as it is fondly referred to by the locals who flock here not just for the satisfying tiffin and lunch fare, but also for tasty innovations like the green masala idli and the button idli, which apparently was made popular here first. In this episode of Gourmet On The Road, we catch the making of the intriguing and rather tasty green masala idli and also partake of a sumptuous breakfast at New Krishna Bhavan. Hope you enjoy this one; take care, stay safe and happy eating.

title: ANAND Dum Biryani Vs. MANI Dum Biryani! Which Famous HOSKOTE Early Morning BIRYANI Should You Try?
description:
#hoskote #biryani #bangalore

mani dum biryani, anand dum biryani, popular hoskote biryani shop, early morning biryani, popular biryani shop,, hosakote, hoskote, bangalore, bengaluru, mutton biryani, biryani trail, inspiring stories, karnataka

The Hoskote early morning biryani draws hundreds of faithful fans who wake up at an unearthly hour every Tuesday, Friday and Sunday to make the 40-km trek to queue up at biryani shops in this town just outside Bengaluru. 

However, for those not completely in the know, some of the most commonly asked questions with respect to this long-standing biryani tradition are: What’s the fuss about the Hoskote biryani? Which biryani should one try, should one try the Mani Biryani or the Anand Biryani? How different are these biryanis? Or are they similar? Which one is spicy, which one is not? What goes into the making of these hugely popular biryanis? Which one came first? And more… 

In this special Gourmet On The Road episode, we revisit these biryanis and compare side by side Hoskote’s most popular early morning biryanis, undoubtedly, in an attempt to answer many of the questions posed. Hope you enjoy this one; take care, stay safe and happy eating! 

Anand Mutton Biryani 
The dominant flavours in this biryani are that of the fresh ingredients, the naati ginger, garlic, coriander,mint etc., followed by a veil of the aromatic spices. Every grain of rice is imbued with its flavours, and the meat is a combination of some soft, juicy pieces and some on the bone, that calls for a bit of effort to get to every bit of it, some fat included. The spicing is gentle and warm. 
Rs. 230 (usd 3.1) 
9/10

Mutton Biryani
The only dish made at Mani Dum Biryani, is unique in its aroma that is redolent of an amalgam of spices combined with meat. Each grain of the rice has absorbed the procession of spices that go into the pot and the fat that is rendered from the meat, this is the sort of biryani that leaves behind a spicy impression on the palate. You can taste the heat of green chillies, and the flavour of the secret spice mix that’s made in Mani’s home. Some of the meat is laced with fat that melts in the warmth of one’s mouth, some pieces though can have a bit of a bite. This is a spicy biryani, and the mosaru bhajji, onion and cucumber raitha helps cool things down.
Rs. 230 (usd 3.1)
9/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 6am to 930am on Tuesday, Friday and Sundays only. The biryani can run out early at times.
Note: It can get crowded, especially on Sundays. Get early to beat a long queue. 

ADDRESS -  Anand Dum Biryani, 1st Main Rd, opposite Chennabyre Gowda Stadium, Swamy Vivekananda Nagar, KHB Colony, Hoskote, Karnataka 562114; tel: +91 97425 00103
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/SNrNDwCBdLnTaXNSA

title: Bengaluru’s SOFTEST IDLIS Takeaway| BRAHMINS’ COFFEE BAR | Idli, Vada, Chowchow Bath | Rerun Episode
description:
#brahminscoffeebar #idlivada #bangalore

support local eateries, takeaway south indian breakfast, brahmins’ coffee bar, idli, vada, chutney, kesari bath, khara bath, shankarapura, bangalore, bengaluru

When it comes to soft, melt-in-the mouth idlis, all roads lead to Brahmins’ Coffee Bar idlis, or at least it did until the current situation. I visit this modest South Bengaluru eatery that’s big on its reputation to see how they are coping with life post covid, and take back a parcel of their entire menu consisting of all of four items only! Are the idlis still as soft? Well, you’ll have to watch this one to find out. Stay safe and happy eating!

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please support local eateries.

Takeaway Dish Review

Idli
A coarse-grained porous idli that allows for the chutney to seep in, you can taste a slight tartness from the fermentation. With the spicy ghatti chutney, that is made of hurukadale, roasted Bengal gram, coconut and  the idli takes on a bold, flavourful avatar. Pour the ‘telu’ or ‘flowy’ mint-coconut chutney over the idli to make for a bite that melts in the mouth.
Rs. 34 (usd 0.45) for 2 idlis 
 
Uddina Vade
It’s a tough act for the vade to follow the idli in takeaway mode, given that the vade is best savoured hot and crispy. However, a saving grace here is the vade is studded with curry leaves, green chillies, peppercorns, fresh coconut, thereby making for a flavourful bite. Soak up the past-warm vade with the chutney to relish the warming heat from the green chillies in the chutney. 
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3) per vade

Khara Bath
BCB’s khara bath is a flavourful one, embellished with curry leaves, toasted lentils, mustard seeds, grated coconut, coriander, tasty enough to be savoured sans the chutney. But if you like it spicy, go ahead and introduce it to the zesty gatti chutney. 
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3) 

Kesari Bath
End your takeaway tiffin with the kesari bath! There’s tonnes of ghee that goes into this sweet semolina and vermicelli concoction and you can taste it in its lush richness. The flavours draw from the tangy fruitiness of the pineapple and the warming cloves. The plum raisins add a sugary pop when you bite into one. 
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3) 

Note: I haven’t rated these as I feel it would be unfair to rate South Indian breakfast items in a takeaway format. Since this is a rerun episode, prices of the dishes may have changed since.

Brahmins’ Coffee Bar is open only in the mornings from 6am to 1030am presently.
ADDRESS -  Near Shankar Mutt, Ranga Rao Rd, Shankarapura, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560004; tel +91 98450 30234
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/bZat92ZaSkeRCVyJA

Brahmins’ Coffee Bar Previous Video Link: https://youtu.be/3tvWL9eJQRM

popular maharashtrian food, support local eateries, takeaway, dine in, street food, comforting food, vada pav, misal pav, bhaji pav, jowar bhakri, pitla, thalipeeth, shrikhand, aamras, puranpoli, aloo rasa, hsr layout, bangalore, bengaluru

I grew up in Mumbai, so every once in a while, I yearn for some Maharashtrian fare. Both, the street food variety - vada pav, misal pav, bhajji, aani (and) also the sort that makes for a satisfying and nutritious vegetarian meal - jowar bhakri, thalipeeth, shrikand puri, aloo rasa and suchlike. A couple of months ago, I was introduced to Mast Marathi, where a Maharashtrian lady entrepreneur, Swati, aided by her Kannadiga husband, Shekar, is serving up an extensive vegetarian menu comprising the flavours of her land. title: CHAAT, North Indian veg Thali, Mithai Takeaway From BHARTIYA JALPAN 75-Year Legacy | Rerun Episode
description:
#bhartiyajalpan #vegetarian #supportlocal

support local eateries, takeaway, bhartiya jalpan, chats, chaats, vegetarian thali, mithai, namkeen, samosa, chole bhature, dahi bhalla, aloo tikki, north indian, bangalore, bengaluru

To quell a chaat and north indian veg food craving, we take away from the Bengaluru outpost of Bhartiya Jalpan, a 75-year-old mithai and namkeen house from Guwahati, Assam. Now whilst takeaways aren’t the best way to savour desi chaats, we found the flavours spot on if you’re looking to savour some chatpata desi fare. Hope you enjoy this episode. Stay safe and happy eating.

Note: This episode was first released in June 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.

Samosa
The dark spiced stuffing makes this a chatpata samosa, the pastry is flakey and still retains its crunch despite being cold. The date chutney is warming and spicy.
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3) per samosa 
8.5/10

Chole Bhature
A popular snack at BJ, the bhatura loses its puffy vigour in takeaway mode, but is still redeemed by the deep flavours of the chole (chickpeas). Definitely a dish that needs to be snacked on when at the eatery as opposed to takeaway.
Rs. 150 (usd 2) 

Raj Kachori
The kachori had become soggy by the time we turned our attention to this yoghurt laden chaat, but the crisp sev and moth beans still offer crunch. The yoghurt is sweet, savoury and sour. 
Rs. 129 (usd 1.7) 

Dahi Bhalla
A dumpling (bhalla) made of rice flour and urad dal, topped with spiced yoghurt, this is the perfect takeaway chaat as the bhalla has soaked up the spicing from the yoghurt and the chutneys. 
Rs. 90 (usd 1.2) 
9/10

Aloo Tikki
A potato patty stuffed with a spice mix and shallow fried on a griddle until crisp, and served with peas gravy. Smash the patty along with the peas to help the chutneys seep into the potato.
Rs. 129 (usd 1.7) 

Bhartiya Jalpan Shaahi Thaali
A tray laden with paneer makhani, aloo mutter, daal, boondi raita, jeera rice, chapatis, a sweet, pickle and papad, this meal option is a sumptuous one. I found the chapatis soft, the paneer soft and creamy, the vegetables cooked the manner they should be and the dal a nourishing accompaniment to the jeera rice. 
Rs. 269 (usd 3.6) 
8/10

Malai Chamcham
The chamcham just dissolves in one’s mouth leaving behind a veil of aromatic sweetness. Highly recommended.
Rs. 38 (usd 0.5) 
9/10

Rabri
Sweetened milk braised slowly over hours and topped with thick cream and nuts, what’s there not to like!
Rs. 81 (usd 1.1) 
8.5/10

Note: I haven’t rated some of the dishes as I feel it would be unfair to rate them in a takeaway format. Since this is a rerun episode, prices of the dishes may have changed since.

ADDRESS -  1138, 100 Feet Road, 13th main, HAL 2nd Stage, HAL 2nd Stage, Indiranagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560038; tel +91 4852 5797
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/yTntaCuwB9quZJEN9

title: Iconic MAVALLI TIFFIN ROOM Veg Lunch Evolves For Takeaway! Rava Idli, Masala Dosa |  Rerun Episode
description:
#mtr #vegetarian #supportlocal

support local eateries, takeaway, mtr, mavalli tiffin rooms, lalbagh, vegetarian lunch, thaali, rava idli, masala dosa, hema malini maiya, bangalore, bengaluru

Step into Mavalli Tiffin Rooms, the city’s oldest eatery, In this throwback episode to see how they have evolved their popular 21-item traditional lunch to a more convenient and packaging-friendly 9-dish mini-meal. 

From revamped, sanitised processes to consolidated menus, this century-old institution is revamping and reworking processes to meet the needs of the current situation. But then, that shouldn’t come as a surprise, because after all, they do have a tradition of innovating through adversities in the past, as illustrated in the invention of the rava idli during the rice famine of the 40s, or the seed for MTR packaged foods that was sown during the 1975-77 emergency. 

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.

Mini Meals
No longer the enormous spread that would be a delicious gateway to a post-lunch slumber, the mini meals is compact in its post-covid avatar. But that doesnt get in the way of making for a satisfying lunch, puri, saagu, rice, rasam, palya, mosaru anna, poppadom, uppinakayi and payasam, the mini meal has all that you need to savour a taste of Mavalli Tiffin Room. 
Rs. 162 (usd 2.1) 
8/10

Masala Dose
Although packed in a foil-lined box, the masala dose is missing its crunch in takeaway mode, understandably, as opposed to when savoured at the restaurant. You can heat it on a tava with a dollop of ghee to make some amends, and the flavours are trademark MTR, the sprightly chutney smeared inside the dosa and the flavourful, bright aloogadde palya. The chutney is rich in coconut and green chilli spice. All in all, makes for a delicious takeaway dose, once you get past the expectation of eating something crisp.   
Rs. 90 (usd 1.2)

Rava Idli
A dish born of a crisis, the rava idli is said to have been invented in the kitchens of Mavalli Tiffin Rooms, when there was a shortage of rice during the famine of the 40s. This is a flavourful rava idli that is rich in yoghurt, embellished with coriander, mint, coconut and topped with toasted cashew, and does spectacularly well as a takeaway. The aloogadde sagu serves well to moisten the idli with its savoury character. 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)

ADDRESS -  Mavalli Tiffin Rooms, #14, Lal Bagh Main Rd, Doddamavalli, Sudhama Nagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560027; tel +91 80 2222 0022
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/546tf138essAZYnT7
Takeaway available at all MTR outlets.

title: RAMADAN MUBARAK! Haleem, Samosa, Shami Kebab, Phirni | SHARIEF BHAI Iftar Takeaway | Rerun Episode
description:
#ramzan #iftar #bengaluru

ramzan food, support local eateries, ramzan iftar, haleem, onion samosa, kheema samosa, kebab, shammi kebab, sharief bhai, koramangala, bangalore, bengaluru

Ramadan Mubarak, folks, wish you peace, happiness and good health, most of all. Join us on this trip down memory lane to an iftar takeaway from Sharief Bhai. Hope you enjoy this rerun; take care, stay safe and strong. 

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.

Takeaway Dish Review

Sharbath
A light and soothing rose milk sharbat to accompany the iftar delicacies. 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.7) per glass.
6/10 

Onion Samosa
I love the sweet crunch of the onions and the crisp, flakey pastry that it is encased in. This is an iftar staple, and Sharief Bhai does a good version of this samosa that is sold at every street corner during Ramzan.
Rs. 70 (usd 0.7) for 4 nos.
8.5/10 

Aloo Cheese Samosa
A well-spiced aloo and cheese stuffing, that lends it a crisp and creamy bite. 
Rs. 105 (usd 0.7) for 4 nos.
7/10 

Gosht Kheema Samosa
The mutton mince is roasted with spices, lending it a deep flavour alongside the onion and peas. On the palate, it is spicy and tangy.
Rs. 130 (usd 0.7) for 4 nos.
8/10 

Paneer Til Kebab
Cubes of paneer, coated in a spicy marinade and deep-fried, the fat in the cottage cheese makes for a moist and spicy bite. If you like your paneer, you will enjoy this snack.
Rs. 100 (usd 0.7) 
8/10 

Gobi Til Kebab
The gobi has a certain sweetness to it as a result of it being deep-fried, it’s missing a crunch in takeaway mode, but other than that makes for a tasty snack.
Rs. 90 (usd 0.7) 
7/10 

Murg Til Kebab Boneless
The chicken, although savoury on the palate, is a tad dry. 
Rs. 140 (usd 0.7) for 4 nos.
6/10 

Murg Shami Kebab
Spiced chicken mince, wrapped around a boiled egg quarter and sprigs of mint and coriander. Makes for a sprightly, comforting snack. 
Rs. 130 (usd 0.7) for 3 nos.
8/10 

Gosht Haleem
Sharief Bhai’s haleem is well-endowed with meat, you bite into meaty strands that have incorporated completely into the pounded wheat, in a flavourful cocoon of warming spices. The brishta, fried onions, lend it a slightly sweetish, flavourful crunch.
Rs. 330 (usd 0.7) for a large portion.
8.5/10 

Murg Anda Kheema Roti
A flakey paratha, topped with a spicy baida (egg) and chicken mince mix, makes for a chatpata, filling snack. Savour it hot!
Rs. 100 (usd 0.7) per roti.
8/10 

Phirni
The phirni is served chilled in a clay pot, a simple dessert made well. You taste the coarse graininess of the rice and the weight of the reduced milk. 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.7)
8/10 

Note: Due to the current uncertain situation, please call the eatery to ascertain the timings and what is available. Prices may have changed since when this episode was originally published a year ago.

ADDRESS -  Sharief Bhai, 68, Jyoti Nivas College Rd, Koramangala Industrial Layout, Koramangala, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560034; tel +91 80957 52222
LOCATION TAG - https://g.page/sharief-bhai---koramangala

title: ANDHRA Lunch Lockdown Takeaway | NAGARJUNA Veg Meals | Chilly Chicken, Sholay Kebab | Rerun Episode
description:
#nagarjuna #takeaway #andhrafood

support local eateries, takeaway, nagarjuna, koramangala, vegetarian lunch, banana leaf meal, chilly chicken, sholay kebab, andhra restaurant, traditional eatery, koramangala, bangalore, bengaluru

In this throwback episode, we visit Nagarjuna, a popular Andhra eatery, to order and take away their popular vegetarian carrier meals, post temperature checks, hand sanitisation and electronic payment, time-appropriate practices that we will need to get used to. The food, packed in tamper proof containers and relished in the comfort of our home,  though remains as comforting as one remembers it from the good old days. Hope you enjoy our this one, take care, stay safe and strong.

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.


Vegetarian Carrier Meals
This weighty meal can feed an army, well, at least 3 to 4 hungry diners. The food is staple Nagarjuna fare with creamy lentils pappu, nourishing sambar, tangy tomato rasam, teh customary koora or vegetable with all the mandatory accoutrements - pappulu podi, curd chillies, payasam, papad, pickle and more served with a humongous bucket of rice. 
Rs. 420 (usd 5.5) 
8/10

Chicken Sholay Kebab
One of Nagarjuna’s most popular boneless chicken appetisers is embellished with loads of curry leaves. The flavours seem a bit sedate in takeaway mode when the dish is eaten around 30 minutes or so after it’s prepared, as compared to the spicy, aggressive bite one encountered when eating this at the restaurant. A tasty bite nonetheless. 
Rs. 305 (usd 4)
7/10

Chilly Chicken
The chilli, spelt with a ‘y’ as opposed to an ‘i’ on the menu is as unique as the dish in itself. Not to be confused with the popular Sino-Indian version, this is Andhra’s ode to its love affair with the chilli. The chicken is moist and juicy, soaking up a gravy made of copious amounts of green chillies, a dish that will have you begging for more punishment if that’s your thing! Definitely not for the faint-hearted though!
Rs. 285 (usd 3.8)
8/10


Note: Due to the current uncertain situation, please call the eatery to ascertain the timings and what is available. Prices may have changed since when this episode was originally published a year ago.

ADDRESS -  138, 1st Cross Rd, KHB Colony, 5th Block, Koramangala, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560095; tel +91 80 4099 6000

title: Tasting VIDYARTHI BHAVAN Bengaluru's Iconic MASALA DOSA In Lockdown Takeaway | Rerun Episode
description:
#supportlocal #vidyarthibhavan #masala dosa

support local eateries, takeaway, vidyarthi bhavan, basavangudi, south bangalore, traditional vegetarian tiffin in bangalore, masala dosa, dose, idli vada, chutney, old world restaurant, traditional eatery, bangalore, bengaluru

In its 78 years of existence, Vidyarthi Bhavan has always served its iconic masala dose within its premises, keeping it strictly outside the purview of delivery services. However the current scenario calls for an entirely new approach in food service, and in keeping with this, this revered South Bengaluru eatery has embraced takeaway as a new way of life, at least for the foreseeable future. I visit Vidyarthi Bhavan to document this change from the past and see for myself how its management is taking all steps necessary to ensure continuity of its delicious culinary traditions in as safe a manner as possible. Hope you enjoy this episode. Stay safe and happy eating!
Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support Bengaluru eateries with takeaway orders in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.


Masala Dosa
The masala dose is now folded twice as opposed to the VB classic one fold, an allowance that the eatery has made for the dose to be rolled into an aluminium foil in order to retain its temperature when savoured at home. The crispy crackle of the dose is now replaced by a whisper of a crunch, but the buttery flavours are still spot on. The dose oozes ghee, and the aloogadde palya is mildly seasoned and creamy. It helps to crispen the dose a bit on the pan just before eating. 
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7) 

Idli
VB’s idlis are the grainy sort, perfect for ladling over chutney and piping hot sambar, before breaking it down to a delicious, spicy mash. If they’re too cold by the time they get to you, steam for a couple of minutes.
Rs. 26 (usd 0.3) 

Uddin Vade
The vade definitely suffers the most casualty when consumed in a takeaway format. Gone is its crisp crunch, that would yield to a porous bite. The only way to redeem the vada is to dunk it into a bowl of piping hot sambar and savour it with a dollop of spicy chutney.
Rs. 26 (usd 0.3) 

Khara Bath
The kharabath travels extremely well, given its moist texture. This tasty dish is studded with onions, fried lentils, coconut flakes and curry leaves, making for a playful medley of flavours and textures.
Rs. 26 (usd 0.3) 

Kesari Bath
End your meal with this luscious semolina preparation, the flavour of the pineapple and cloves is quite pronounced. The dish is mellow in its sweetness, save for the pop of extra sweetness when you bite into a toasted raisin.
Rs. 26 (usd 0.3) 

Note: Due to the current uncertain situation, please call the eatery to ascertain the timings and what is available. Prices may have changed since when this episode was originally published a year ago.

Vidyarthi Bhavan has also launched a contactless ordering system, send a whatsapp message ‘Hi’ to +919164926465

title: Inspiring NOON’S BIRYANI | This Family Biryani Shop Went From Tough Times To Customers Across India!
description:
#supportlocaleateries #smallbusiness #bangalore

noon’s biryani, popular biryani shop now sells in 18 cities, support eateries, small business, restaurants, takeaway, mutton biryani, chicken biryani, hsr layout, bangalore, bengaluru

When I first met Mr. & Mrs. Mohammed a few months ago to film an episode of Gourmet On The Road, they were barely getting by. The pandemic had quite literally taken the wind out of their enterprise, a tiny 3-table eatery in a nook of South Bengaluru where Mr. Mohammed and his son would sell the biryani made by his wife at home. However, the sincerity with which this affectionate couple shared the making of the biryani in our video seems to have won for Noon’s Biryani legions of fans resulting in a new lease of life for this neighbourhood shop that now has customers across India, with requests from overseas patrons too for their special biryani spice blend. I caught up with them for a quick chat a few weeks ago when I popped into their store to take away some biryani, and also left with a healthy dollop of inspiration based on what the family had managed to achieve notwithstanding the current challenges of life. I hope you enjoy this impromptu inspiring vlog, take care, stay safe and happy eating.

if possible, please spare a thought for the many neighbourhood restaurants and eateries that have given us abundant culinary pleasures and now depend on our support to make it through these gloomy days, one small takeaway order at a time. 

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: lunch - 1pm to 4pm; dinner - 630pm to 10pm
Note: Closed on Mondays; they make the mutton biryani only on weekends. Whilst you will get a biryani for lunch, dinners are usually takeaways only. Do call them before you visit to ensure you get our biryani. Although you can have a quick biryani meal here, it is best to take away. Order ahead to ensure you get what you want. 
ADDRESS -  Noon’s Biryani, 664, Sector 7, HSR Layout, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560102; tel: +91 80501 60888/ 88926 02786

title: Popular Biryani Takeaway | MEGHANA FOODS | Vegetable, Aloo, Chicken, Mutton | Rerun Episode
description:
#lockdown #biryani #supportlocaleateries

support local eateries, takeaway meal, meghana foods, biryani, vegetable biryani, hyderabadi chicken biryani, boneless chicken biryani, aloo biryani, mutton biryani, koramangala, bangalore, bengaluru

Hi folks, hope you are doing well. In this throwback takeaway biryani review, we visited Meghana Foods, a establishment that seems to have a formidable following for its biryanis that are mostly made in the Hyderabadi style with loads of masala. Purists may balk at the eatery’s top seller, a boneless chicken biryani that to me seemed like a culinary intersection of Sino-Indian and Hyderabadi fare! Love it or hate it, you certainly can’t ignore Meghana Foods!

And to allay consumer fears in a covid world, they seem to be following many of the practices - temperature checks, hand sanitation, sealed takeaway packs, etc. - that will have to be the norm when it comes to eating out. Hope you enjoy this one, take care and stay safe.

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support local eateries.

Special Veg Biryani
A biryani that panders to a vegetarian’s biryani craving. The rice is flavourful, and the side of tossed vegetables draws clever inspiration from a mirchi ka salan in its flavours. 
Rs. 230 (usd 3) 
8/10

Aloo Dum Biryani
The potatoes are fried to a delicious brown and have absorbed the flavourful character of the fried onions and the spices. With the mildly spiced biryani rice, it makes for a tasty combination.
Rs. 214 (usd 2.8) 
7.5/10

Chicken Biryani
A biryani that is made in the traditional Hyderabadi style with loads of masala, this is the biryani to try here. The meat is juicy, moist and flavourful, cooked perfectly to the bone.
Rs. 242 (usd 3.2) 
8.5/10

Chicken Boneless Biryani
Tender morsels of boneless meat, tossed in a spicy batter are served as an accompaniment to fluffy grains of biryani rice. Though a dish that is far removed from a traditional Hyderabadi biryani, it still commands legions of fans, I suspect partly because the spicy morsels of meat and generous portion of rice served makes it ideal for sharing. 
Rs. 248 (usd 3.3) 
8/10

Mutton Biryani
The meat was a tad chewy and dry and lacking succulence, the rice though had a nice depth of flavour. Not a biryani that I would order again. 
Rs. 301 (usd 4) 
7/10

Note: Due to the current uncertain situation, please call the eatery to ascertain the timings and what is available. Prices may have changed since when this episode was originally published a year ago.

title: What I Do To ORDER TAKEAWAY FOOD SAFELY | Taste, Safety & Peace Of Mind! Rerun Episode
description:
#safefoodtakeaway #supportlocalbusiness #supportrestaurants

Hi folks, I hope you are doing well. This is a video that I have put together based on requests I have received from many of our viewers to illustrate do’s and don’ts when ordering takeaway food.

I want to share with you measures that I take when I am ordering food, from a taste, safety, and peace of mind perspective. Hope you find this useful, I have also placed some of my research reference links below. Stay safe and happy eating!

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support the eatery and others like this establishment that need help in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.

Link to Gourmet On The Road Takeaway playlist: 
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLri_37vf6mmrBWUIaryRMdvcL8p1rmrY1 
Link to Gourmet On the Road Recipes playlist:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLri_37vf6mmqmRCMkXZxRG--nGqQL3SPs

Links to references I have looked up to determine if eating outside food is safe:

Specifically, coronaviruses are thermolabile, which means that they are susceptible to normal cooking temperatures (70°C). Therefore, as a general rule, the consumption of raw or undercooked animal products should be avoided. Raw meat, raw milk or raw animal organs should be handled with care to avoid cross-contamination with uncooked foods.
Source: WHO https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200221-sitrep-32-covid-19.pdf

Food containers and packaging. There's no evidence of anyone contracting the virus that causes COVID-19 after touching food containers and food packaging. Many restaurants are now offering no-contact takeout and delivery to lessen the risk of transmission.

Still, if you're concerned, it's reasonable to follow general food safety guidelines. Wash your hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and water after handling takeout containers, and then transfer food to a clean dish using clean utensils. Wash your hands again before eating. After disposing of containers, clean and disinfect any surfaces that had takeout containers on them.
Source: Mayo Clinic, https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/expert-answers/can-coronavirus-spread-food-water/faq-20485479
Food Standards Australia & New Zealand, https://www.foodstandards.gov.au/consumer/safety/Pages/Can-COVID-19-be-transmitted-by-food-or-food-packaging.aspx

COVID-19 is a respiratory disease spreading from person to person. It’s not a foodborne disease. There’s no evidence to suggest people will get infected by swallowing the virus in, or on, food or drink.
Source: Food Standards Australia & New Zealand, https://www.foodstandards.gov.au/consumer/safety/Pages/Can-COVID-19-be-transmitted-by-food-or-food-packaging.aspx

title: This 80-Year-Old Has Seen Famines But Never This! Support NEW MODERN HOTEL Takeaway | Rerun Episode
description:
#supportlocalbusiness #newmodernhotel #vegetarian 

support local eateries, takeaway meal, new modern hotel, lockdown, new modern hotel, basavangudi, south bangalore, traditional vegetarian food in bangalore, south canara food, traditional vegetarian food, thatte idli, set dosa, khara bath, kesari bath, rice rasam, rice sambar, anna saaru, lunch, old world restaurant, traditional eatery, bangalore, bengaluru

Mr Padmanabha Adiga, has seen famines, plagues, political unrest and other disruptions in the 60 years he has helmed this old Bengaluru institution, New Modern Hotel, but says the current situation is something else altogether! An optimist though, he and his sons prepare to do what it takes to tide this South Canara vegetarian eatery through. Inspiration aside, I also take away a simple but nourishing anna-saaru meal in addition to some of their popular tiffins and sweets. Hope you enjoy this episode, take care, stay safe and happy eating.
Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support the eatery and others like this establishment that need help in the current situation. Please do support local eateries.

Set Dose
There’s a hint of tart sweetness in these soft, fluffy dose that are perfectly suited for takeaway. With the nourishing sambar, vegetable saagu and chutney, it makes for a wholesome light meal. 
Rs. 48 (usd 0.6) 

Thatte Idli
Soft and porous, the thatte idli breaks under its own weight. The sambar, pleasing to the palate with its sweet acidity is perfectly suited to impregnate the idli with its mildly spicy fervour. 
Rs. 29 (usd 0.4) 

Khara Bath
As you place the khara bath in your mouth, the savoury aroma of the onion is what you taste first, followed by the moist crunch of the tomato and the grainy bite of fresh coconut. Spice things up with the chutney. 
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3) 

Kesari Bath
Redolent in the flavour of cloves, this isn't a kesari bath that’s dripping in ghee. Which makes for a tasty indulgence minus the guilt.
Rs. 27 (usd 0.4) 

Anna Sambar
A sambar rich in lentils and grated coconut, made well, the vegetable, ladies finger, still has its crunch intact. 
Rs. 43 (usd 0.6) 

Anna Saaru
The tomato plays a dual role in this pleasing South Canara tilli saaru, more popularly known as tomato rasama here in Bengaluru. The tomatoes are the foundation of this tart broth, and also offer a fruity crunch in the diced tomato that is perhaps added when the rasam is near cooked. 
Rs. 43 (usd 0.6) 

Mysore Pak
Rich in ghee, the fresh mysore pak crumbles under its own weight. When you place it in the mouth, it dissolves into a lush, buttery pool of deliciousness.
Rs. 18 (usd ) per piece 

Jehangir
Crisp, crunch and moist, this well-made old-fashioned mithai is a popular sweet at NMH.
Rs. 18 (usd ) per piece 

Note: Due to the current uncertain situation, please call the eatery to ascertain the timings and what is available. Prices may have changed since when this episode was originally published a year ago.
ADDRESS -  New Modern Hotel, 143, Dr.A.N. Krishna Rao Road, Vishweshwarapuram, near Minerva circle, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560004; tel +91 80 2661 2625/ +91 98458 27655
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/k2pQw9UHzsXtZZus7

Link to earlier New Modern Hotel episode: 
Tasting SOUTH CANARA VEGETARIAN THALI At NEW MODERN HOTEL Bengaluru | Making Of BADAM HALWA |Chiroti

title: Support Mr. & Mrs. Iyer's 60-Yr-Old IYER MESS | Takeaway A Tasty Veg BANANA LEAF Meal! Rerun Episode
description:
#vegetarian #takeaway #bangalore

support local eateries, iyer mess, takeaway meal, iyer meal, pure vegetarian meal, carrier meal, vegetarian lunch, banana leaf meal, sambar, rice, kootu, veg meals, bangalore, malleshwaram, bengaluru

Mr Venkatesh and Mrs Kamala Iyer serve up Tamil and Kerala Brahmin traditions in their tiny eatery, Iyer Mess, established by the former’s father in 1959. The food is simple, yet delicious, cooked by Mrs Iyer and honestly priced at Rs. 80 for a sumptuous vegetarian banana leaf meal. 
As I catch up with the Iyers when I get this takeaway meal, I can't help but feel sorry for this elderly couple who are trying hard to grasp the realities of business in the new normal. From 200 meals a day, they are now reduced to under 30, and despite the financial hardships that they endure, they have held onto their staff, lodging and boarding them at home to ensure they are safe. Spare a moment for establishments like Iyer Mess even as you watch this episode. Take care and stay safe.

Vegetarian Meal
A simple meal, the Iyer Mess banana leaf is laden with everything that one needs for tasty sustenance. With a menu that changes everyday, the spread - rice, sambar, rasam, kootu, poriyal, thayir, pickle and papad - is nourishing, and of the sort you would relish at a Tamil home blessed with a good cook. And offers great value.
Rs. 80 (usd 0.9) Rs. 100 takeaway

Note: This episode was first released in May 2020 and is being rerun to support the eatery and others like this that need help.

ADDRESS - Iyer Mess, No 4/3, West Park Road Between 7th and 8th Cross, Malleshwaram West, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560003; tel: 098860 78290

title: She Is Doing Her Best To Make It Through This Difficult Time | The Lighthouse |🙏Support Restaurants
description:
#gourmetontheroad #supportlocalrestaurants #smallbusiness 

support eateries, small business, restaurants, takeaway, the lighthouse restaurant, coastal cuisine, mangalorean food, konkani food, alle piao, stuffed pomfret, unicorn special prawns, rmv layout, sadashivnagar, bangalore, bengaluru

It is a rather difficult time for eateries and restaurants everywhere. Barely had they somehow scraped through last year, the ones that managed to survive that is, the current scenario yet again threatens hundreds and thousands of livelihoods that depend on this sector. In this ‘support restaurants’ vlog, I return to The Lighthouse Restaurant to meet lady entrepreneur, Prathiksha Nayak and learn how they are coping, and to also taste some delicious dishes that I missed out on when I was here last. Whilst we must all stay safe and take adequate precautions for ourselves and our loved ones, if possible, please spare a thought for the many restaurants and eateries that have given us abundant culinary pleasures and now depend on our support to make it through these gloomy days, one small takeaway order at a time. Take good care of yourself and stay safe; this too shall pass. God bless.

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 1130am to 11pm; please check on the current timings owing to the restrictions that may be in place. 
Note: The restaurant also delivers through online delivery platforms.  
ADDRESS -  The Lighthouse Restaurant, No. 62, 80 feet road, Near MS Ramaiah Hospital, opposite to apple store Devasandra, Village, RMV 2nd Stage, Ashwath Nagar, R.M.V. 2nd Stage, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560094; tel: +91 70262 36661

title: Tasting 8 Varieties Of Holige At MANE HOLIGE! Bele, Badam, Jackfruit, Gulkand, Dates, Pineapple..
description:
#holige #maneholige #bangalore

popular holige shop with 23 varieties of holige, mane holige, traditional, bele, coconut, badam, gulkand, dates, pineapple, jackfruit, carrot, khoa, sweet store, kuruk thindi, savouries, snacks, bengaluru

In Karnataka, we love our holige or obbattu, traditionally a lentil and jaggery mix stuffed in a flour dough, rolled out, fried, and served hot, slathered with ghee. However, when it comes to variety, all roads seem to lead to Mane Holige which dishes out a mind-boggling 23 types of holige, hot and fresh every single day! I visit their Jayanagar store in the run-up to Ugadi and taste 8 of the holiges on offer - including the classic bele and kai to the rich khoa, badam, dates and an unusual jackfruit version too! No matter what your preference, you’re bound to find your holige fix here!  Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Bele Holige 
Rs. 15 (usd 0.2)
9/10

Pineapple Holige
Rs. 28 (usd 0.4)
7/10

Carrot & Khoa Holige
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
7.5/10

Badam Holige
Rs. 35 (usd 0.5)
10/10

Jackfruit Holige
Rs. 40 (usd 0.5)
8.5/10

Dates Holige
Rs. 18 (usd 0.2)
8/10

Gulkan Holige
Rs. 22 (usd 0.3)
7/10

Kai Holige
Rs. 15 (usd 0.2)
8/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 9am to 9pm
Note: The place does get crowded, especially on weekends and festivals. The holiges are made to order and entails a bit of a wait, which is a good time to check out their extensive kuruk thindi section They have multiple stores, Basavangudi, Kathriguppe, Vijayanagar, RR Nagar, Malleshwaram, Basaveshwar Nagar in Bengaluru, in addition to stores in Hubli, Mangalore and Mumbai. You should be able to locate one closest to you on google maps.  
ADDRESS -  Mane Holige Jayanagar, 126, 30th Cross Rd, 4th Block, Jayanagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560011; tel: +91 98865 84789

title: Cooling Down With Bengaluru’s Latest TENDER COCONUT SHAKE Trend! ‘Original' YELNEER KATTE
description:
#coconutshake #yelneerkatte #bangalore

trending coconut dessert, popular coconut shake, tender coconut shake, ice cream, summer cooler, dessert, milkshake, smoothies, healthy coolers, yelneer katte, basavangudi, bangalore, katte special, ice cream, small business

With the mercury rising, Bengaluru’s denizens seem to be turning to the yelneer or tender coconut water shake, a dessert trend that seems to be the flavour of the season. I ventured out to Yelneer Katte, supposedly the store that began this rage in the city to decipher for myself what the fuss was all about. Hope you enjoy this short and icy-cool episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Katte Special
Coconut flesh crushed with coconut milk, cream and nuts, this is the one to have if like me you prefer tasting the ‘coconutty’ character. The nuts and raisins also add to the nutty flavor and thick texture of this shake, the pomegranate seeds provide a fruity pop and the swirl of condensed milk a rich, creamy finishing touch. The sweetness is just right.
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7)
8/10

Yelneer Mango Shake With Vanilla Ice Cream
A loaded shake, coconut flesh ground with coconut water and fresh mango, topped with vanilla ice cream, chocolate syrup, nuts, fresh mango and some condensed milk. A tasty milkshake, but one cannot taste much of the coconut as it is overpowered by the ice cream, chocolate sauce and a copious amount of sugar. 
Rs. 100 (usd 1.3)
6.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 11am to 9pm
Note: The place does get crowded especially on weekends. Do plan your visit accordingly. Yelneer Katte also has branches in BTM 2nd Stage, Jayanagar and Malleshwaram, you will find it on google maps.  
ADDRESS -  Yelneer Katte, 57, E Anjaneya St, Gandhi Bazaar, Basavanagudi, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560004; tel: +91 83173 14636 
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/JRKuwfs3QxA6rKUGA

title: TARAYI COASTAL CUISINE | This Family Eatery Is A Labour Of Love! Fish Thali, Ghee Roast, Crab Masala
description:
#seafood #mangalorean #bengaluru

family eatery, st thomas town, east bangalore, new restaurant, coastal cuisine, fish thali, fish fry, pomfret, mackerel, fish fry, prawn ghee roast, crab masala, chicken curry, small business

Tarayi, a tiny three-table eatery in St. Thomas Town, East Bengaluru, was born of homemaker Freeda Ananth’s desire to share the culinary legacy of her late mother and to set up a small business of her own. So, with the support of her husband, Vijay Ananth, this soft-spoken lady ventured out as a restaurateur just a couple of months ago, and in a relatively short span of time has managed to make an impression on the neighbourhood with her rendition of Mangalorean-Kundapur fare laced with a touch of Kerala influence. I visited Tarayi to taste their limited but tasty homestyle offerings, and to also help share the word on this family enterprise that’s a true labour of love. Hope you enjoy this episode, take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Prawn Ghee Roast
This ghee roast masala exudes a slight sour twang followed by the warmth of the chilli and spices. The prawns are cooked just right, delicately ‘springy’ on the bite, swaddled in the grainy textured masala with the lushness of ghee.  
Rs. 270 (usd 3.6)
9/10

Black Pomfret Fry 
The masala is napped rather lightly on the fish, allowing for the pomfret to shine in its fresh flavours. The skin is cooked to a perfect crisp.
Rs. 250 (usd 3.3)
8.5/10

Seer Fry
Rs. 280 (usd 3.7)
8/10

Crab Masala
Loved the aromatic masala, onions, tomatoes and spices, soaked up by the plump, meaty sea crab. The sweet crab meat contrasts beautifully with the savoury notes of the masala. If you love crab, this is certainly a must-order when here.
Rs. 240 (usd 3.2)
10/10

Fish Thali
A satisfying thali, complete with modest portions of mackerel curry and fry, in addition to sambar, rasam, vegetables, boiled rice… perfect if you’re looking to savour Mangalorean fare on a budget.
Rs. 150 (usd 2)
8/10

Kheema Ball Curry
A pleasing curry, I found the meat ball a tad pasty and giving up the texture of the flour used to bind the mince together.
Rs. 120 (usd 1.6) for half portion
7/10

Chicken Curry
A homestyle curry, thin in its consistency but rich in the flavour of the masala. Goes well with the neer dosae. 
7.5/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: breakfast and lunch - 8am to 430pm; dinner - 630pm to 10pm; closed on Mondays.
Note: This is a tiny eatery with barely three tables; if dining here, be prepared for a bit of a wait. Best perhaps to order in, they are registered on Dunzo for now.
ADDRESS -  Tarayi Coastal Cuisine, #7, 3rd Main Road, karavalli Road, KK Halli, St Thomas Town, Post, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560084; tel: +91 97319 95671/ 96111 02133/ 080 4972 2888
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/juaSDpVbdQvjvp4w9

title: Rajamma’s MADHAVAN PARK BAJJI SHOP | This 30-Year-Old Cart Is Serving Up Delicious Nostalgia!
description:
#streetfood #jayanagar #bengaluru

popular bajji shop in jayanagar, south bangalore, vegetable, pakora, bonda, capsicum masala bajji, baby corn fry, potato, bread pakora, mirchi bajji, balekai bajji, raw banana, small business

Rajamma and her husband, Basavaraj, set up a pushcart in a street corner of Jayanagar to fry and sell hot bajjis. Thirty years have passed since, the neighbourhood has evolved beyond recognition but Rajamma’s Madhavan Park Bajji Angadi, or shop, has stood constant at the same spot. Her husband has since retired, and today, she is helped by her sons, as they continue to serve delicious vegetable bajjis at honest prices to customers who visit not only for the scrumptious fare but also for the comforting nostalgia of yesteryear. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating! 


The bajjis here are served fresh and are rather enjoyable, my favourites were the capsicum, baby corn and also the masala vade. But it is the sort of place that you can't go wrong no matter what you order.

Capsicum Masala Bajji

title: This Biryani Is Steamed In Bamboo For Two Hours! NRK BAMBOO BIRIYANI Food Truck, Mysuru
description:
#biryani #streetfood #mysore

biryani food truck, nrk bamboo biryani, mysuru, bamboo biryani, mutton biryani, chicken biryani, chicken tawa fry, small business

On my last trip to Mysuru, I visited this food truck that cooks an unusual biryani, layered and steamed in bamboo. Helmed by a relatively new food entrepreneur, Ramamurthy, who was left with no option but to move to Mysuru and begin this mobile eatery to support his family after losing his life’s savings, the bamboo biryani is a result of his culinary passion and kitchen experiments. This version of the biryani that is steamed in bamboo for a couple of hours, isn’t what one may traditionally expect, but certainly makes for an interesting dish to taste! Check it out if you find yourself in Mysuru. Hope you enjoy this short and sweet episode, take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Mutton Biryani 
The sort of biryani that tumbles onto the plate when semi-cooked meat masala is placed in the bottom of a bamboo cylinder, topped with aromatic rice and egg,  and steamed for a couple of hours. The thick masala clinging to the meat serves to moisten the rice and the meat, some pieces soft and yet others that warrant a bit of a chew. The bamboo lends its aroma to the preparation.
Rs. 200 (usd 2.7)
7.5/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 6pm to 1030pm; Monday holiday
Note: They also serve a chicken biryani at Rs. 150; the vibe is that of a food truck in an open area.

banana leaf lunch with mega star puneeth rajkumar, puneeth rajkumar, yuvarathnaa, sandalwood, karnataka, baale yelle oota, jolada rotti, vegetarian, basaveshwar khanavali, gandhinagar, bengaluru, bangalore

Hi folks, this is a very special episode. Karnataka youth icon and Sandalwood superstar, Puneeth Rajkumar, joins me in a traditional jolada rotti oota at the legendary North Karnataka eatery, Basaveshwar Khanavali in Gandhinagar, Bengaluru.
