title: GANGA’S MUDDE MANE | Homely Gowda Cuisine| This Brave Couple Makes A Fresh Start Despite Challenges!
description:
#traditional #gowdafood #bangalore

new gowda cuisine eatery, vegetarian thali, non veg meal, nalli fry, ragi mudde, kheema unde curry, mutton peas pulav, kaal soup, boti gojju, chicken tava roast, small business

A sudden loss of occupation forced Hemanth Kumar to deploy his life savings and rustle up an eatery to support his family. Seeing her husband struggle, Nalini gave up her teaching job to support him in this enterprise that aspires to serve homestyle Gowda food. I visited Ganga’s Mudde Mane one afternoon to meet and motivate the brave couple, and along the way tasted an elaborate spread. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Kaal Soup 
An aromatic soup that serves well to whet your palate. The tomato conveys a pulpy texture laden with the meaty broth.
Rs. 40 (usd 0.6)
8/10

Brain Fry
Flavoured with the lightest touch of spice, pepper and curry leaves, the ‘bheja’ is cooked to perfection and melts in its rich buttery lushness when placed in the mouth. If you love the brain, a must-order here!
Rs. 150 (usd 2.1)
10/10

Chicken Tava Roast
Marinated in a green chilli, ginger garlic paste, it is the freshness of the mint that shines through the masala. I found the chicken a tad chewy. 
Rs. 190 (usd 2.6)
7.5/10

Boti Kal Goju 
A thick preparation enlivened with the starchiness of raw banana and nourishment of lentils, the boti is cooked through well. 
Rs. 170 (usd 2.3)
8/10

Mutton Kheema Ball Curry
The kheema unde is rich in its meatiness and is complemented by the green chilli and coriander. Eat this hot to prevent the gram flour, used to bind the meat, from making its presence felt on the palate.
Rs. 180 (usd 2.5)
7.5/10

Chicken Kheema Goju 
Tiny cubes of chicken tossed in a tasty masala. What makes this dish interesting are flecks of yam that bring its earthy flavours. 
Rs. 150 (usd 2.1)
7/10

Nalli Fry 
A weighty lamb shank, some of the meat has a bit of a bite, but as you work your way to the core of the nalli, the meat is tender. There is depth of flavour from the spices and the pepper. 
Rs. 380 (usd 5.2) for two large pieces, the price for this varies by weight. 
9/10

Veg Meals 
A vegetarian will enjoy this simple but homely assemblage with as much gusto as a non vegetarian. From the scrumptious dill fritters to the comforting sprouts saaru and rasam, each dish bears the mark of a talented home cook, in this case, Nalini Hemant Kumar. I would happily order this with a non-vegetarian side.
Rs. 80 (usd 1.1)
8/10

Mutton Peas Pulav 
Made three days a week, this is a pulao that is moist, gentle and aromatic. The aroma of the whole spices is what one tastes on the palate alongside the faint warmth of green chillies whose heat has been toned down by some coconut milk that goes into the pulao just before it is placed on dum. The meat in the pulao is soft and has a bit of fat ribboned through it, the peas are endearing in their soft bite.
Rs. 200 (usd 2.8)
8.5/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Breakfast and lunch - 8am to 4pm; dinner - 6pm to 930pm; Monday holiday
Note: Ganga’s Mudde Mane is a new eatery run by a family with a spartan team at present. Do support them as they try to find their feet. 
ADDRESS -  Ganga’s Mudde Mane, 3rd cross, Manjunath Nagar, Kanakapura Rd, Raghuvanahalli, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560062; tel: +91 98806 54833/ 97415 49363/ 99161 63217

title: Tasty, Rustic Breakfast At NANI HOTEL, Vijayapura | Popular Ghee MASALA DOSA, Bele Bhath And More...
description:
#traditional #villagebreakfast #ruralbangalore

popular breakfast spot 50 kilometres from bangalore, village eatery, bengaluru, rural bengaluru, nani hotel, masala dosa, dose, idli, vada, bisi bele bhath, chitranna, tomato rice, masala vade, kesari bath, coffee

Given its modest beginnings as a village eatery in a hut six or seven decades ago in Vijayapura, S. Narayan Rao, the late founder of Nani Hotel may have found it hard to fathom its current immense following that draws Bangaloreans to drive 50 kilometres for breakfast here. Having discovered its tiffin delights on a motorcycle ride a couple of months ago, I returned to savour breakfast, catch up with the owning family and patrons to find out what’s special here, including their much-loved Nani Hotel Masala Dosa. Hope you enjoy this episode, take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Tuppa Masala Dosa
The ghee masala dosa is the top draw with patrons here. Smeared with a spicy chutney as it roasts, the dosa is ladled with a dollop of potato palya and a top-up lashing of ghee to ensure the tuppa is what customers taste in plenty. The result is a golden-brown dosae that is slightly thick and biscuity in its crunch and lush with ghee, cradling within its fold a creamy, flavourful palya. The chutney makes for a spicy accompaniment.
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8) 
9/10

Idli 
Rs. 5 (usd 0.1) 
8/10

Uddina Vade 
Rs. 10 (usd 0.15) 
7/10

Bele Bhath/ Tomato Bhath/ Puliyogare/ Chitranna/ Kesari Bhath
Rs. 25/ 40 (usd 0.3/ 0.5) for half/ full portion 
8/10 (my favourites were the tomato bhath and bele bhath 

Masala Vade 
Rs. 5 (usd 0.1) 
7/10

Coffee 
Rs. 6 (usd 0.1) 
7/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 730am to 1030am, 230pm to 430pm
Note: The eatery is located in a tiny alley, if you’re in a four-wheeler, it is best to park in the main Gandhi chowk or nearby and find your way on foot here. It’s a short walk and will help build your appetite! :-)

title: Tasting A Delicious, Traditional Kerala Meal | KAPPA CHAKKA KANDHARI | Ramassery Idli, Appam & Stew
description:
#traditional #keralacuisine #bangalore

best kerala restaurant, bangalore, bengaluru, koramangala, traditional, malayali food, kappa chakka kandhari, appam and stew, karimeen, pearlspot fry, kappa fish curry, pazham kanji, pidi kozhi curry, duck roast, kappa vada, tapioca, ramassery idli, appam and stew, puttu, mutton coconut fry, meen pollichathu, tender coconut pudding, kandhari ice cream, payasam, chef regi mathew

The folks behind Kappa Chakka Kandhari restaurant take their food rather seriously, after all their menu is a showcase of Malayali fare based on their collective memories of growing up in Kerala. And spearheading this unique ‘nostalgic’ culinary initiative is Chef Regi Mathew, who has spent more than a decade extensively touring his home state, exploring recipes and connecting with cooks across homes, community kitchens, and even toddy shops. The resulting food is a labour of love, with ingredients sourced from micro-regions in Kerala to match the provenance of the dish, for instance the rice for the fabled Ramassery Idli comes from Palakkad, the home of the idli, the karimeen (pearl spot fish) from Vaikom, Kottayam, and so on… This fastidious approach to sourcing also seems to extend to the kitchen hands at KCK too, who hail from traditional kitchens and homes in ‘God’s own country’. In this episode, I partake of a lavish lunch that spans across a dozen preparations, made possible by their innovative menu approach that allows for diners to savour a string of delicacies in the course of a meal. Hope you enjoy this one, take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Note:
The set menus at Kappa Chakka Kandhari are priced upwards of Rs. 475 (usd 6.5) and in addition to a tasting of seven preparations, include a beverage and dessert too. Additional add-ons (limited servings), kappa vada, koorka fry, ramassery idli with chicken curry, are priced at Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) per dish.  

Rajayogi Meal
A set menu that’s fit for a king, this smorgasbord of a dozen dishes is sheer indulgence! Begin with juicy prawns in a coconut-kokum masala that is steamed in a petite banana leaf pouch, spicy ‘touchings’ of needle fish, the plumpest soft shell crabs, and a delicately flavoured pearl spot fish draped in a robust, toddy shop masala, amongst other delicacies that include a peppery chicken peralan and a slow-cooked mutton coconut fry. After an interlude of a sweet, sour and spicy, pineapple-nendram relish, the main courses troop out - pidi, tiny rice dumplings steeped in coconut milk and served with a flavourful simple chicken curry, a velvety mutton stew and appam combo, and a prawn puttu biryani that hits the spot. For dessert, there’s much to choose from, we tried the chilli-pricking kandhari ice cream and the luscious tender-coconut cloud pudding.
Rs. 1475 (usd 20.3)       
9/10 (overall) The pearl spot fry, mutton fry, soft shell crab, pineapple nendram relish, mutton fry, appam and stew  - 10/10

Kappa Vada
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) add-on serving
8/10

Koorka Fry 
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) add-on serving
8/10

Ramassery Idli With Varutharacha Chicken Curry & Sambar
The idli is aromatic and soft, slightly pasty, and has a bit of a weight that lends to combining with the sambar or spicy chicken curry.  
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) add-on serving
9/10

Ayakora Nellikai Masala Fry
A fish fry inspired by frugal tribal traditions, the fish is spiced with a paste of sun-dried gooseberries, green peppercorn and kandhari, bird’s eye chilli. Rs. 375 (usd 5.2)
8.5/10

Cloud Pudding
10/10

Kandhari Ice Cream
9/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Lunch - 12pm to 330pm, Dinner - 7pm to 11pm
Note: If in a group, order more than one set menu, it’s a great way to gourmet graze through the diverse flavours of Kerala. 
ADDRESS -  Kappa Chakka Kandhari, 438, 18th Main Rd, 6th Block, Koramangala, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560095; tel: +91 63646 71010/ +91 80 2552 1010

title: Tasting North Bengaluru’s Best Pizza At SIDDY’S PIZZA | Veg Margherita, Chicken, Sicilian Pepperoni
description:
#pizza #yelahanka #bangalore

best pizzas, north bangalore, bengaluru, siddys pizza, pizza recipe, pizza, pizzeria, margherita, smoked chicken, garlic bread, pepperoni, handmade pizzas, italian, authentic sicilian style pizzas, siddy, siddhanth sawkar, yelahanka, bangalore

When Siddhanth Sawkar was forced to close his café and home catering-turned-food truck brand, Spitfire Barbeque, owing to the pandemic, he spent a couple of months mulling his next move, making pizzas. Not just a generic version as dished out by fast food chains! Instead, he dug deep into his experience as a culinary student in Southern Italy, to open a pizzeria serving Sicilian style pizzas in his erstwhile North Bengaluru café in Yelahanka New Town. Siddy’s Pizza, as I discovered during a leisurely visit, is a one-man passion enterprise, where Siddy, as Siddhanth is known, does everything from taking the order to putting together the pizzas to serving customers who quite often chat with him as the cheese-laden flavourful pies bake in the oven. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Garlic Butter Bread
Pillowy soft and gushing with garlic-infused buttery flavour; the butter is molten as the bread comes out of the oven! Changes your perspective of what simple garlic bread can be! The cheddar cheese dip makes for an indulgent accompaniment.
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9)
9/10

Classic Margherita & Cheese - Large
Its dough fermented for a few hours, the pizza is firm and toasty, drooping at the edge, burdened under the weight of a generous topping of cheese. The sharp, spicy notes of the homemade tomato sauce, salsa semplice, is softened by the mozzarella. 
Rs. 350 (usd 4.8)
8/10

Smoked Chicken & Cheese - Large
The juicy personality of the chunky, smoked chicken franks take over the palate the moment you bite into this cracker of a pizza, followed then by the slightly, sweet crunch of the onions. The cheese and tomato sauce play second fiddle to the meat and onions. If you love smoked chicken, this pie is a must-have!
Rs. 420 (usd 5.8)
10/10

Classic Pepperoni & Cheese - Large
Lush in virgin olive oil, this is a classic Sicilian style pizza, its ‘bready’ texture quite similar to a focaccia. There’s plenty of mozzarella that sits atop the pizza, followed by the spicy sauce and onions. But it is the fat-laden savoury fervour of the pepperoni that is the hero of this pizza! This pizza is also the sort that would make for a great midnight snack when left over in the refrigerator.
Rs. 650 (usd 9)
9/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 12pm to 1030pm
Note: Closed on Mondays. The pizzas are loaded and large, so do plan your order accordingly. ADDRESS -  Siddy’s Pizza, 810, HIG, 1st & 2nd Stage, B-Sector Yelahanka, New Town Main Rd, Yelahanka New Town, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560064; tel: +91 96118 09810

title: This Couple Serves The Authentic Taste Of Nellore | CHEPALA PULUSU | VIJAY KITCHEN | Andhra Bhojanam
description:
#nellore #andhrafood #bangalore

nellore andhra restaurant, vijay kitchen, brookefield, whitefield, bengaluru, andhra meals, fish curry, chepala pulusu, fish fry, vegetarian bhojanam, rr chilli chicken, mutton pepper ghee roast, biryani, chicken fry biryani, nellore, small business

With a culinary lineage that goes back to Hotel Manju, supposedly the first table-service restaurant in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh in the sixties, Sashidhar Reddy and his wife, Vijayalakshmi, moved to Bengaluru from Nellore little over a year ago to open Vijay Kitchen, to serve dishes made to traditional family recipes. I visited this modest eatery set in the ground floor of their home in the suburb of Brookefield, where I not only savoured a delicious Andhra Bhojanam but also caught the making of an iconic Nellore Chepala Pulusu, a sour and spicy fish curry. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating. 

Plate Rice Meals
Served on a banana leaf tray, the rice meals is a simple but satisfying affair that consists of two vegetables, one dry and the other moist, a sambar, rasam and a nourishingly tasty pappu to keep company with the anam (steamed rice) and flavoured rice. There is also a sweet to round off the meal.
Rs. 99 (usd 1.4)
8/10 

Chepala Pulusu (Sour and Spicy Fish Curry)
Made by his wife, Vijayalakshmi, to a recipe that goes back to Sasidhar Reddy’s grandmother, the Chepala Pulusu is a must-try here. A sour and spicy affair, the fish curry is made the evening before, thereby allowing for the fish to soak up the vivacious character of the tamarind, raw mangoes, chilli powder and the secret fenugreek spice blend. 
Rs. 180 (usd 2.5)
10/10

Mamdikaya Royyalu (Mango Prawns)
A tangy preparation that juxtaposes fresh flavours of shrimp to the tart fervour of raw mangoes. Taste it with the annam (rice) to tone down some of its tangy flavours.
Rs. 250 (usd 3.4)
9/10

Chepala Fry (Fish Fry)
Chinese pomfret or lake pomfret naped in a pleasant masala; the skin is fried to a crisp.
Rs. 150 (usd 1.4)
7/10
 
Royyalu Avakkai
A spicy, homemade prawn pickle that makes for a great combination with steaming hot rice.
8/10
 
Mutton Pepper Ghee Roast 
The meat is moist and juicy, coated with coarsely ground pepper and tossed in the buttery lushness of ghee. The meat is cooked twice, first a roasted fry with masala, and then tossed around in hot ghee. 
Rs. 250 (usd 3.4)
9/10

RR Chilli Chicken
This dish should come with a ‘chilli hotness’ warning! Not for the faint-hearted, there is little else in this dish other than the chicken and tonnes of green chilli. The result is a unique taste that’s fiery at first but also the sort that endears itself once you get past the ‘suffering’! If you like it toned down, tell them so and they will toss it in some ghee.
Rs. 150 (usd 1.4)
8/10

Chicken Fry Biryani
A dish that was introduced as a means to consume leftover biryani rice, topped with chicken fry, the chicken fry biryani today is more popular than the Nellore biryani here. One can taste the warming flavours of the biryani spices in the kushka, the rice, that makes for a great combination with the robust tomato-onion rich masala of the chicken fry. 
Rs. 180 (usd 2.5)
8.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Lunch - 12pm to 4pm; Dinner - 7pm to 11pm 
Note: This is a family run enterprise that is doing its best to cope with the realities of the new normal. The food is great, and the family does its best in its service assisted by a few staff members. 
ADDRESS -  Vijay Kitchen, 533, B Block, AECS Layout, Marathahalli, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560037; tel: +91 82970 90789/ 70759 01966
LOCATION TAG - https://g.page/vijay-kitchen?share

title: SRI CHIKKAVEERANNA SWEETS | This 72-Year-Old Village Shop Serves PURE GHEE MITHAI & KHAARA Items!
description:
#mysorepak #badamhalwa #vijayapura

popular sweet shop in rural bangalore, vijayapura, bengaluru, sri chikkaveeranna sweets, mysore pak, badam halwa, ghee jilebi, pure ghee sweets, traditional mithai, family run, tuppa, ghee red rice avalakki

In 1948, Chikkaveeranna opened a sweetmeat stall in Vijayapura, then a sleep hamlet located fifty kilometres from Bengaluru. The stall would travel from village fair to village fair selling mithai and khaara made of pure country ghee. 72 years on, village ghee may no longer be easily available, but Suresh Chikkananjundappa, his grandson, tends to the traditions of his ancestors in the ghee sweets and savouries that he personally prepares with his family and dedicated workers. Their mysore pak is hugely popular, made to a special technique where the gram flour is lightly roasted with some ghee, before finding its way into the paaka or sugar mixture. However, the tuppa jilebi, with the batter fermented overnight in clay pots, the rich badam halwa made with homemade khoa, and a seriously addictive red rice avalakki mixture, all made with pure ghee, are also must-haves when at this tiny sweet shop. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Tuppa Jilebi
Made of a batter that is fermented overnight in a clay pot, and fried in pure ghee, the result is a white jilebi that crackles with a sticky bite and unburdens its ghee-laden sweetness with just a tinge of sourness. 
Rs. 440 (usd 6) per kilo 
9/10 

Tuppa Avalakki
Red rice puffed to a crisp in a bath of boiling ghee, comes together with ghee-roasted cashewnuts, curry leaves, Bengal gram and generous sprinkling of spices to make a seriously addictive khaara or mixture.  
Rs. 560 (usd 7.7) per kilo 
9/10 

Mysore Pak
Soft and crumbly, lush with ghee, this is the sort of Mysore Pak that dissolves on the palate with the light lilt of cardamom, when fresh. You can taste the weight of the gram flour, especially in the tiny clumps that have held on to the ghee as the gram flour is lightly roasted before it finds its way into the sugar syrup or paaka. The hero ingredient in this mithai though is the ghee that makes it Sri Chikkaveerana’s most popular mithai for over seven decades.
Rs. 560 (usd 7.7) per kilo 
10/10 

Bene Murukku
One of the few items here that is made in oil, the murukku though crunchy and flavourful with cumin and carom seeds and the nuttiness of sesame, feels a bit spartan when tasted in the company of the other heavyweights here.
Rs. 280 (usd 3.8) per kilo 
8/10 

Badam Halwa
Garnished with chironji seeds and slivers of pistachio and almonds, the halwa is rich with the reduced milk solid, ghee and the grainy bite of coarsely ground almonds. Although, the Mysore Pak is traditionally more popular here, the badam halwa comes a close second. 
Rs. 640 (usd 8.7) per kilo 
9.5/10 


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 1030am to 9pm 
Note: They have no branches, to taste what I tasted, visit the original shop located in Vijayapura town by following the google coordinates given below. To ensure their fare is always fresh and given the family-run nature of this sweetshop, Sri Chikkaveeranna Sweets prepares limited quantities each day. It is best to call ahead and ensure you get your quota of the mithai and khaara items here.
ADDRESS -  Sri Chikkaveeranna Sweets, Shidlaghatta Road, Vijayapura Town, Karnataka 562110; tel: +91 98458 88499
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/xqwjrMmLnYZCM9Ct8

title: ROYAL MESS | This Couple Serves Memorable Hyderabadi Mughlai Food At Their Mysuru Home Eatery!
description:
#restaurantathome #mysore #mughlai

home eatery in mysore, royal mess, mughlai, hyderabadi cuisine, mutton kheema, mutton masala, butter chicken, korma, biryani, kheer, sameena khanum, homestyle food in mysore

When Sameena Khanum’s husband retired from his job overseas, she decided to do something on her own to support the family. Her love for cooking led her to open a tiny eatery at home with two tables only, catering initially to college students yearning for home-cooked meals. Entirely self-taught, Mrs. Khanum serves up a repertoire of Hyderabadi-Mughlai dishes, assisted by her husband and children. A meal here is not just about delicious sustenance but also about the warming hospitality with which one is welcomed and served, as I discovered when I dropped into Royal Mess late one evening. Hope you enjoy this episode; take care, stay safe and happy eating!

Mutton Kheema
The mutton kheema is coarse and grainy, cooked with meat on the bone, that results in a deep-flavoured, warming dish. The sort that makes it a must-try here.
Rs. 350 (usd 4.8) for a large portion.
9/10

Mutton Masala
Flavoured with the gentle sweet flavours of fresh tomato and the savouriness of onions, the masala is tasty. The meat is soft, there’s a bit of fat that one needs to work through. One could request for slightly less fat, makes for an enjoyable dish. 
Rs. 400 (usd 5.5) for a large portion.
8.5/10

Chilli Chicken
A homestyle chilli chicken that is spiced with green chillies and red chilli powder and plenty of garlic. There are onions and capsicum too. A chilli chicken that isn’t as spicy as one would expect it to be. 
Rs. 220 (usd 3) for a large portion.
7.5/10

Butter Chicken
A rich cashew nut gravy that had a tad too much dried fenugreek garnish for my liking, the meat, a bit of a bite. 
Rs. 220 (usd 3) for a large portion.
7/10

Chicken Biryani
Made with long-grained basmati rice, the flavourful masala is an amalgam of fried onions, tomatoes, yoghurt and Mrs. Khanum’s home-blended spice mix. The biryani had cooled down a bit, rendering the rice slightly dry and the meat a fibrous bite. Ensure that you arrive at Royal Mess when the biryani is freshly made to savour this preparation.  
Rs. 175 (usd 2.4) 
7.5/10 

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 1230pm to 1030pm 
Note: Portions are large and easily shared between two people. Given the nature of the eatery, located in a home, it is best to call ahead and go to ensure you get what you are looking for. They also accept orders in advance for special dishes.
ADDRESS -  Royal Mess, 4th Cross Rd, S S Nagar, Siddique Nagar, Bannimantap, Mysuru, Karnataka 570015; tel: +91 99024 19612
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/nbAk8UeeQcvzUvo2A

title: Exploring SAPA Sourdough & Pastry | Mysuru’s Charming New Dessert Café | Must-Try Chocolate Tart!
description:
#mysore #coffee #desserts

new coffee house in mysore, café, sapa sourdough and pastry, bakery, gokulam, chocolate tart, cheesecake, tea cake, flat white coffee, wheelchair accessible

On a recent trip to Mysuru, I ventured into this cafe that in a short span of time seems to have charmed denizens of this city of palaces with its refreshing vibe, scrumptious bakes and delectable pastries. Hope you enjoy this short video of my tryst with SAPA Sourdough & Pastry, where I gave my heart to a decadent salted caramel chocolate tart! Take care, stay safe and happy eating! 

Chocolate Chip Tea Cake
Buttery and gooey with the chocolate chip, this is the sort of cake that could potentially make for  a great accompaniment to the coffee. I found it a bit crumbly though.
Rs. 110 (usd 1.5)
7/10

Oat Crumble & Vanilla Sour Cream Cheesecake
A rich cheesecake with a slightly sour twang that is balanced by an oat crumble crust. With its delicate whiff of vanilla, this makes for an enjoyable cheesecake. 
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2)
8/10

Chocolate Tart
A must-try dessert here, layers of dark chocolate and salted caramel ensconced in a ‘biscuity’ chocolate tart shell, topped with pistachio crumb. 
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2)
10/10

Coffee
Rs. 150 (usd 2)
7/10

title: Traditional Breakfast At New SHIVALLI | Kotte Kadubu, Rajamudi Dosa, Kuchalakki Ganji, Ragi Ambli
description:
#mysorehighway #vegetarian #breakfast

popular restaurant on mysore highway, shivalli restaurant, mtr shivalli, mudagere, channapatna, bangalore mysore road, kotte kadubu, rajamudi rice, neer dosa, dose, kuchalakki, boiled rice, finger millet, ragi ambli, healthy food, healthy breakfast, highway breakfast, wheelchair accessible

One of the earliest eateries on the Bengaluru - Mysuru route, Shivalli has recently emerged after an extensive renovation that imparts this 20-year-old popular highway destination a breezy, contemporary vibe that comes as a breath of fresh air in current times. It is heartening to note though that the food remains as traditional as ever, in fact, with some ‘new’ additions seeking to convey to diners the wholesome flavours of the good old days. On a recent drive to Mysuru, I stopped by for a delicious breakfast of nourishing porridge, kuchalakki (boiled rice) ganji, tenginkai haalu (coconut milk) ganji, ragi (finger millet) ambli, and also tasted a scrumptious neer dosa made of the very special Rajamudi rice, and their much-favoured kotte kadubu. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating! 

Kotte Kadubu
Soft and slightly grainy, the kadubu is a much-sought-after breakfast delicacy here; savour it with their flavourful south canara sambar and spicy ‘kai’ chutney
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
8/10

Thenginkai Ganji
Rice soaked in coconut milk and topped with a lashing of ghee. Pleasant in its aroma, flavour and texture, this is a porridge to savour if you’d like something light post a heavy meal the evening before. The cucumber served alongside provides an element of crunch. 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
7/10

Kuchalakki Ganji
Boiled rice, sourced from Kundapur, cooked simply with salt and served with a drizzle of hot ghee. Comforting in its nourishing flavours, the rice retains its form and is soft to the bite, having lent some of its starchy heft to the broth. The hand pounded chutney of green chillies, fresh coconut and rock salt provides a spicy edge to the ganji. 
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
8/10

Ragi Ambli
The cumin is dominant in its flavour in this earthy but sumptuous broth of finger millets. There is also a delicate tinge of green chilli heat and pepper. 
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7)
7/10

Neer Dosa
The Rajamudi rice lends a brownish tinge to the dose, and also a crusty crunch. The dose is roasted with generous lashings of ghee, ensure you ask for your dose to be kadak. The flavours are quite unlike a traditional neer dose; although enjoyable on its own when hot, the bela kai, jaggery with fresh grated coconut makes for a delicious companion. If you like a touch of spice, there is the chutney too.
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
9/10

Filter coffee
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
8/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 7am through 930pm, open all days. 
Note: On google maps, the eatery comes up as MTR SHivalli restaurant, it has no connection to MTR restaurants. Google maps will take you to the eatery on the left hand side of the highway enroute to Mysuru; however the eatery that we visited is on the opposite side a few metres down the road.
ADDRESS -  Mudagere, Channapatna, Bangalore, Mysore Rd, Channapatna, Karnataka 562160; tel: +91 99805 12450
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/UVjUhU6qW44ZycHAA

title: Lunch At LAKSHMAN MESS | Mysore’s Famous Naati (Local) Non Veg Eatery |Mutton Pulav, Curries & Fries
description:
#mysuru #lakshmanmess #muttonpulav

popular eatery in mysuru, must-try, non vegetarian, naati style cuisine, local, affordable, mutton pulav, mutton curry, mutton fry, chicken kebab, khaima unde, inspiring story, mysore 

Armed with recipes gleaned from his mother, Lakshman quit his job at a spice shop, to begin a small pushcart operation to serve the non-vegetarian delicacies of his home. Bit by bit, the reputation of his food grew, and after 20 years of eking out a living on the streets, Lakshman was finally able to move into a tiny shop where customers could finally dine away from the bustle of the street. A few years later, the landlord wanted his space back, and faced with no option, he tore down his home to build a permanent space for Lakshman Mess. A eatery that has all of Mysuru thronging here for their honestly-priced limited menu that includes a delicately flavoured pulav, homestyle meaty preparations cooked by Lakshman and his son, Satya, with masalas ground at home. Hope you enjoy this episode. Take care, stay safe and happy eating! 

Chicken Kebab
Mild in its flavours, the batter has a flavourful crunch that could have enlivened the taste of the kebab had it seeped all the way into the meat.
Rs. 90 (usd 1.2)
7/10

Mutton Chops
Chunks of meat that have a bit of bite, cooked in a delicious masala that is dominant in the flavour notes of coriander and mint, and the aroma of the special spice blend. The pepper coconut milk adds a layer of creamy warmth. This is the sort of dish that makes for an appropriate side dish to taste with the demure pulav. 
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4)
9/10

Mutton Pulav
Delicately flavoured and moist, the Lakshman Mess pulav employs a combination of the long-grained basmati and short-grained rice varieties. You taste the faint edge of the green chili alongside the mint and coriander, the whole spices too aren’t the sort that dominate the palate. The meat is tender and juicy. I loved the pulav as is for its demure character, but if you like yours spicy, savour it with the meaty curries.
Rs. 150 (usd 2.1)
9/10

Kaima
Minced mutton balls simmered in a spicy gravy, spicy when compared to the mutton curry and pulav. 
Rs. 50/ 100 (usd 0.7/ 1.4) for half/ full portion
8/10

Mutton Fry
Curry leaves meet soy sauce in this mutton stir-fry, a dish created for the benefit of locals who wanted something different, I found this a slightly discordant fit on the Lakshman mess menu.
Rs. 105 (usd 1.5) 
7.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 7am through 11pm, closed on Mondays.
Note: The mutton pulav and boti is quite popular and runs out soon, get there early to taste it.. 
ADDRESS -  No.87, 1,k 46/1, Santhepete Rd, Behind Mysuru City Corporation, KR Mohalla, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570024; tel: +91 821 243 0269/ +91 99868 45777
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/yiV2cW3wQy3RPDdE9

title: Must-Try Mysore’s Very Popular KUKKARAHALLI LAKE Breakfast Tradition | DEEPU GAADI & MYSURU KAAPI
description:
#mysuru #breakfast #coffee

popular breakfast spot in mysuru, food in mysore, mysore food trail, traditional, south indian tiffin, dosa, dose, set dosa, thatte idli, filter coffee, kukkarahalli lake, mysore 

Every city has its popular morning traditions, Mysuru too has its share of them. A delicious one though seems to be that of going for a long walk around Kukkarahalli lake followed by a steaming, hot breakfast at a food rickshaw, Upahara Darshini, popularly known as Deepu Gaadi. The popular draw here is the set masala, smaller than your usual dosa, perhaps to let its fans indulge in more than one of these scrumptious beauties. On a recent dash into Mysuru, I took time out to experience half of this popular tradition, no points for guessing which half, followed by a delicious cup of filter kaapi. Hope you enjoy this breezy watch. Take care, stay safe and happy eating!
 
Breakfast At Upahara Darshini (Deepu Gaadi)
I paid Rs. 70 (usd 1) for a single thatte idli with a vade, and a plate of set masala dose. The thatte idli is soft, a bit pasty, but goes well with the chutney. The set masala dosa though is the dish to try here. The dose is well roasted, crisp and translucent in the centre, revealing flecks of a spicy red chutney smeared within. 
8/10 overall 

Filter Coffee At Mysuru Kaapi
The coffee is thick, strong and just the sort of beverage to wash down an indulgent ghee-laden breakfast.
Rs. 12 (usd 0.2)
8/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Breakfast commences from 7am through 11am.
Note: Get to Kukkarahalli lake and ask for Deepu Gaadi, located in a lane opp the lake. 
ADDRESS -  
tel: +91 99729 22227 (Deepu Gaadi), +91 81057 47679 (Mysuru Kaapi)
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/SrNc6V99rbrMPZXv5

title: Tasting Karnataka’s Famous BANNUR MUTTON In Bannur | Bandur Sheep | Lunch At BANNUR MILITARY HOTEL
description:
#bannurmutton #biryani #karnataka

bannur mutton explained, bandur sheep, bandur village, malavalli, mandya, bannur, mysore, mutton biryani, mutton fry, mutton kheema, bannur military hotel, ramaswamy hotel, mutton meal

The Bannur mutton, Karnataka’s most prized mutton, isn’t actually from Bannur. It is the meat of an indigenous variety of sheep that hails from Bandur, a village located between Malavalli and Bannur near Mysuru. Prized for its juicy tender meat, the sheep was traditionally sold in village shanties in Bannur, ergo the acquired moniker, Bannur. I drove to Bannur to learn more about this sheep and also catch a mutton meal at a family eatery, Bannur Ramaswami Military Hotel, that showcases this very special meat in its homestyle preparations. Hope you enjoy this episode, stay safe and happy eating! 

Nati Koli Kurma
The chicken has a bit of a chew, a character of the free range chicken, there’s a bit of skin too that adds to the flavourful character of the homestyle curry, which is the sort that goes well with the ragi mudde.
Rs. 110 (usd 1.5) 
8/10

Kaima Sambar
Dumplings of rough-ground mutton simmered in a curry, the meat has a springy bite to it. There is also some dil that lends its aroma to the meat balls. 
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) 
8.5/10

Mutton Fry
The fat of the Bannur mutton is ribonned through the meat that is deep in its slightly salty, savoury flavours. The curry isn't too spicy, and is quite happy playing second fiddle to the flavour of the meat.
Rs. 150 (usd 2.1) 
8.5/10

Bannur Mutton Biryani
You can nose the kasoori methi (dried fenugreek) in the aroma of the biryani, there’s the warming heat of the red chillies and spices that you can taste on the palate, a touch of tang from the tomatoes… the kolam rice is tasty all in itself, also having absorbed the character of the meat. The meat is soft and moist, deep pink in its colour and veined with fat. This is a biryani you should eat hot, do not allow it to cool down for the fat tends to congeal. 
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2) 
9/10 

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 9am to 11pm
Note: Like with most popular eateries, this one too has its share of imitators. Make sure you visit the right one to savour the original Bannur mutton. Do refer to the google maps coordinates below.
ADDRESS -  Bannur Military Hotel (Ramaswamy Hotel), MM road Bannur, near Bharath petrol bunk, Bannur, Karnataka 571101; tel: +91 94489 79333
LOCATION TAG - https://g.page/bannurmilitaryhotel?share

title: Serving Delicious Wood Fire Idlis For 50 Years | Original KOTE IDLI KANAKAPURA| 4 Idlis Rs. 10 Only!
description:
#idlichutney #kanakapura #karnataka

must try idli shop, kote idli, popular village style wood fire idlis, kempu chutney, red chutney, kanakapura, kanakapura road, karnataka, near bengaluru, bangalore, idli chutney, popular breakfast, inspiring story, culinary tradition

After completing the 10th grade, a young lad decided to help his father in their village idli shop in Kanakapura, 60 kilometres from Bengaluru. Half a century on, Mr. Ramchandra has remained steadfast to his father’s culinary tradition, steaming fragrant idlis over a wood fire. A one-man army, he procures the ingredients, prepares the wood to fuel the decades-old stove, soaks the rice and lentils, grinds and carefully ferments the batter, before rising at 4am each morning to make a spicy chutney, and steam over 3000 idlis, 500 in a batch, that run out before noon! Working with the energy and enthusiasm that is hard to imagine in a modern-day sextagenarian, Ramchandra swears by the philosophy of “cheap and best”, in his words, selling four piping-hot idlis for only Rs. 10, or Rs. 2.50 a piece! The quality and appeal of the soft, fluffy idlis are such that patrons don't mind a two-hour drive just to breakfast at this old-fashioned Kote Idli Mane. Hope you enjoy this episode, stay safe and happy eating!

Idlis
The idlis are soft and porous, yielding with a slightly pasty texture in its weight. The size of the idlis are such that you can happily savour about four to six without feeling its burden. The spicy, roasted gram and red chilli chutney makes for a delicious accompaniment to the fragrant idlis. 
Rs. 10 (usd 0.1) for four idlis
9/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 630am to 12noon
Note: Do not be misled by another Kote Idli shop that has opened at the entrance of the street where the original Kote Idli is located. Venture into the lane to find the original Kote Idli, a nondescript village house, where you will find Mr. Ramchandra preparing the idlis.
ADDRESS -  Kote Idli, #147, Agrahara Rd, opp. Hamsavahini" School, Fort, Kanakapura, Karnataka 562117; tel: +91 99865 15860
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/7ERXcvWWdjiEN8DE7

title: Making Of Famous Village Style HALLI JONNE BIRIYANI | From Pushcart To Popular Biryani Eatery!
description:
#biryani #jonnebiryani #bangalore

popular jonne biryani shop, donne biryani, bengaluru biryani, jayanagar, mutton biryani, chicken biryani, mutton chops, chilli chicken, chicken curry, leg piece, mutton kheema, inspiring story, jayanagar, bangalore

As the oldest son in his family of modest means, Ningaraju was compelled to look for work as a student. His fondness for food and his ability to recall the flavour of dishes from local eateries led him to set up a pushcart on the outskirts of Bengaluru, serving a self-taught village-style biryani. In the beginning, “things were difficult, sometimes humiliating and marked by periods of self-doubt”, recalls Raju, as he is popularly known. Giving up though wasn’t an option, driven also by the necessity to provide for his family. Slowly, the popularity of his mild-flavoured biryani served in cups of dried banana leaves, jonne, grew, and so did the scale of his enterprise. Today, this resilient entrepreneur’s Halli Jonne Biryani occupies prime real estate in Jayanagar, South Bengaluru, and is frequented by over 500 customers on any given day. I catch up with Raju as he makes the biryani before sitting down to a tasting of most of the dishes on the limited menu here. Hope you enjoy this episode. Stay safe and happy eating!

Kaal Soup
The soup is peppery, infused with the freshness of coriander.
Rs. 150 (usd 2.1)
8/10

Khaima Goju
The mutton mince is coarse, there’s a rustic rawness to the masala that is smoothed by the fluffy texture of the idli.
Rs. 130 (usd 1.8)
8.5/10

Chicken Leg Piece
Cooked soft and tender to the bone, you can taste the pungency of ginger garlic that’s softened by the acidity of tomatoes.
Rs. 130 (usd 1.8)
8/10

Mutton Fry
Some of the meat is soft and tender, with a bit of fat, others have a bit of a bite. You can taste the coriander and the pointed heat of green chillies in the masala. The flavours are mild but satisfying.
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9)
9/10

Mutton Liver Fry
The peas make for a nice touch in this gentle gravy; some of the liver pieces though were a bit tough.
Rs. 130 (usd 1.8)
7.5/10

Chilli Chicken
An unusual chilli chicken, you can taste the fresh flavours of the green chilli as opposed to its heat. The mildest chilli chicken I have ever tasted.
Rs. 120 (usd 1.6)
8.5/10

Chicken Kabab
The kabab is scrumptious and flavourful, the chicken is moist and seasoned well, but doesn’t hold on to the spicing of the batter.
Rs. 120 (usd 1.6)
7/10

Chicken Biryani
The seeraga samba rice is stained pastel yellow with a tinge of green, reminding one that this biryani hasn’t borne the brunt of a masala overload. Not the sort of biryani that one will smell from a mile away, the flavours though are the sort that reveal to the palate the ingredients that have gone into its making. You can taste the tingling heat of the green chilli, the freshness of the coriander and mint, the veil of fragrance from the spices register. A biryani that also brings to the fore the flavour of the seeraga samba rice. If you like it spicy, you may need to taste it with the curries that are served alongside the biryani. 
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9)
8.5/10

Mutton Biryani
The mutton has rounded off the flavours of biryani, as opposed to the chicken version. The meat is tender and moist, its fat laden flavours the sort that compels one to draw a bit of the meat in every scoop of the rice. These biryanis are perhaps the lightest donne biryanis one has tasted.
Rs. 180 (usd 2.5)
9/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 730am to 4pm; 6pm to 10pm
Note: Closed on Mondays. This is a rather busy restaurant, prepare to share tables if you get one, there is a stand and eat option too for those in a hurry. If you’d like to savour the Halli Jonne fare in peace, best to takeaway or order in. 
ADDRESS -  Halli Jonne Biryani, #44, 4, 13th Main Rd, opp. BHS College, 4th T Block East, KV Layout, Jayanagar, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560011; tel: +91 2663 3886/ 96637 11666
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/ofKkRxRW9uwhv4XY8

title: CALICUT’S TOP FOOD TRAIL Pt 1| Paragon, Amma Hotel, Rahmath, Bombay Hotel, MS Sarbath, Kumaran Chips
description:
#kozhikode #gourmetontheroad #kerala

most popular, must-try restaurants in calicut, must-eat-at eateries, popular food destinations, paragon restaurant, amma hotel, rahmath hotel, bombay hotel, bhaskarettan ms sarbath, kumaran’s banana chips, kozhikode chicken biryani, mutton biryani, fish fry, evening snacks, biryani tea, kozhikode, kerala

When it comes to vying for the best food destination honours in ‘God’s own country’, Kerala, Calicut, or Kozhikode, seems to trump the popularity charts. And for all the right seasons, we found out during our visit to this coastal destination last year. Here’s part one of our top Kozhikode picks: from the iconic Paragon, Kerala’s most popular restaurant, to the fabled fish fry and curry destination, Amma Hotel, to Rahmath’s traditional biryanis, the evening snacks at Bombay Hotel, Bhaskarettan’s Sarbath and scrumptious banana chips at Kumari’s, this compilation covers it all. Save it for your next visit to Kozhikode, and stay tuned for part 2 as well. Hope you enjoy this one, stay safe and happy eating!

title: Karnataka Food Legend, SIHI KAHI CHANDRU Invited Me To His Hit TV Show, Bombat Bhojana!
description:
#gourmetontheroad #kripalamanna #sihikahichandru 

sihi kahi chandru, karnataka’s most popular food television personality, actor, director, producer, bombat bhojana, food show, television, star suvarna, interview, cooking, recipe, dosa, dose, dilruba dose, recipe, behind the scenes, bangalore

When it comes to food personalities in Karnataka, Sihi Kahi Chandru is perhaps one name that everyone knows. An acclaimed actor, director and producer, he has endeared himself in the hearts of every Kannadiga for his prolific food shows on television. Over the last couple of years that I have been producing Gourmet On The Road, I have received numerous comments requesting for a collab with him, so it was a pleasant surprise and an honour to receive a call from him inviting me as a guest to Bombat Bhojana, his show on Star Suvarna. In this vlog, I share a behind the scenes peek on my participation in the show and a quick conversation with the legend himself.

Hope you enjoy the vlog, and do tune in to the episode of Bombat Bhojana on Star Suvarna on 30th January at 12pm IST.

title: This Man ‘Invented’ The WHITE PAANI PURI! Tasting BANGARPET CHAAT At Ramesh Chit Chat In Bangarapet
description:
#chaat #bangarapet #karnataka

bangarpet chaat, chaat innovation, white paani, vegetarian, white paani puri, pani puri, masala puri, sev puri, bangarpet tikki, pot gulkand salad, pizza paani puri, street food, pani puri, bangarapet, kolar district, kolar gold fields, kgf, karnataka

Son of R. Panduranga Setty, who is said to have begun the Bangarpet Chaat tradition in 1974 in Bangarapet, named so (Bangar = gold, pete = town) for its importance as a town that connected the erstwhile Kolar gold fields to Bengaluru, 80 kilometres away, young Ramesh, wasn’t happy just continuing with the family legacy. A desire to create something new led to the invention of the ‘white paani’, a clear liquid that though as innocuous-looking as water, packs a potent, spicy punch. And thus began the tradition of the Bangarpet Paani Puri, that has spawned a few hundred namesakes in Karnataka. Ramesh however continues to operate out of his tiny shop in a bylane in Bangarapet, serving customers personally and experimenting constantly to add to his spicy, tangy repertoire. I spend an evening with him, tasting his wares, and return impressed with his childlike enthusiasm that doesn’t seem to have waned in the least despite being in the business for nearly four decades, his latest creation, a pizza inspired paani puri! Hope you enjoy this episode, take care and stay safe.

White Paani Puri
A simple assemblage of green peas, onions, carrots and coriander, stuffed in a semolina and flour puri, topped with the potent ‘white paani’. The spiciness of paani though is toned down by the creaminess of the peas and the crunch of the onions. A simple, clean flavoured paani puri that allows one to appreciate every component singularly, as well as in its completeness. 
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
8.5/10

Special Dahi Puri
Embellished with rose petals, this chaat is a riot of flavours and textures. The crispiness of the chaat components and the spice of the masala play second fiddle to the creamy, sweet richness of the yoghurt that is fortified with Horlicks, milk powder and sugar. 
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7)
10/10

Floating Paani Puri
The floating paani puri is a spicy affair, the spicy white paani goes into the puri and also floats the puri. The moist crispness of the puri is endearing as is the crunch of the spiced peanuts and the sev, despite the fresh crunch of the onion, cucumber and tomato, there is no getting away from the chilli heat of the sea of white paani. 
Rs. 40 (usd 0.6)
9.5/10

Tikki Masala Bangarpet
A take on the Bengaluru masala puri, this is puri topped with spicy chutney, sweet chutney, peas, garam masala, squeeze of lime, onions, carrots, coriander, sev and puffed rice. It has all the components that you would expect to find in a chaat without being overdressed! 
Rs. 30 (usd 0.4)
8.5/10

Special Sev Puri
The flat papdi base for this chaat is fried in ghee which gives it a rich, ‘biscuity’ bite embellished with the nuttiness of sesame seeds. You can taste the edge of garlic in the chutney that the fresh ingredients are tossed in. 
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7)
9/10

Bhelpuri
A typical bhel but with the addition of the peas gravy that goes into every plat of chaat here, I found this rendered the puffed rice soggy and that didn’t quite work for me.
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
7/10

Pizza Paani Puri
I doff my hat to Ramesh on his latest attempt to innovate and bring a foreign flavour to the bylanes of Bangarapet. However, with regards to its taste and appeal, some may fancy it, yet others question its existence. 
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4)
7/10

Spiced Amla
Rs. 30
7/10

Pot Gulkand Salad
Rs. 30
8/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 4pm to 10pm
Note:
ADDRESS -  Ramesh Chit Chat, Vijayanagar Road, near nandhi medical, Vivekanand Nagar, Bangarapet, Karnataka 563114; tel: +91 94481 85272
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/s93eS1YseBT6Sdoy7

title: Blockbuster KGF - KAVERI GODAVARI FOODS | Tasty Curries, Dosa, Parotta Cooked In Wood Pressed Oil!
description:
#foodtruck #tamilnadufood #bangalore

traditional tamil nadu, salem style, non-vegetarian, street fare, food truck, kalakki, mutton kari dosa, nati chicken, mutton chops, brain fry, pepper fry, podi dosa, east bengaluru, bengaluru 

When Prabhu, an automobile engineer with a major car company chose to pursue his entrepreneurial calling in food, a food truck didn't come across as a surprise to his father who encouraged him to pursue his dreams. After getting his hands on a Tempo Traveller, he drove it to Pune to fabricate a food truck that would serve up the meaty cuisine of his Tamil heritage with a smattering of influences from Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka as well. Back in Bengaluru, this culinary enterprise on wheels, Kaveri Godavari Foods, is slowly but surely gaining popularity in the neighbourhood it is parked in. Adding to its appeal is the fact that all dishes here are prepared at Prabhu’s home and cooked in wood-pressed oils extracted in the family’s oil mill. I drive 20 kilometres to East Bengaluru to catch up with this passionate engineer and experience the streetfood vibe here whilst savouring a bunch of tasty preparations - egg kothu parotta, kalakki podi dosa, mutton parotta, chops, nati chicken, brain fry and more. Hope you enjoy this episode. Stay safe and happy eating!
 
Mutton Brain Fry
Tava-fried with eggs in an aromatic, homemade masala, this is the dish to taste if you love brain meat; it quite simply melts in the mouth. The eggs also help make more of the dish that is perfect, mopped up with some parotta.
Rs. 150 (usd 2)
9/10

Kuzhambu Kalakki
A Salem egg staple, egg cooked skilfully such that it encloses within its folds a gooey, spicy egg mixture. Traditionally, this is eaten at the end of a non-vegetarian meal in Salem.
Rs. 15 (usd 0.2)
7.5/10

Mutton Kari Dosa
A fluffy dosa topped with coarse mutton mince, eggs and served with a spicy curry, this is the sort that makes for a satisfying one-dish meal or a big late-night snack.
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9)
7.5/10

Mutton Chops
Goat chops cooked in a gravy rich in the flavour of dark-roasted spices, this is a dish that will bring me back to KGF. The meat is the sort that peels away from the bone in a juicy, peppery bite. Order a plain dosa to soak up the curry.
Rs. 150 (usd 2)
10/10

Podi Dosa
One can smell the nutty aroma of the peanut oil that this dose has been roasted in. The dosa is smeared with an Andhra podi whilst being fried to a near crisp. A dose that goes ‘crunch’ from the first bite to the last, with a slightly tangy edge.
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8)
9/10

Nati Chicken Pepper Fry
Rs. 200 (usd 2.7)
7.5/10

Chicken Stuffed Parotta
Rs. 100 (usd 1.9)
7.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

title: SWAD - N - SWAD | This RAJASTHANI Couple Is Serving Delicious, HOME-COOKED Traditions Of Their Land!
description:
#homecooked #rajasthanifood #bangalore

rajasthani food, vegetarian, non vegetarian, besan gatta, sev tamatar, lahsuni bhindi, tangdi kebab, rathodi chicken, junglee maas, laal maas, makki ki roti, roti, kheer,  inspiring story

Hailing originally from Surajpura Lotiyana village in Ajmer district of Rajasthan, Jithender and his wife, Renuka Tak, moved to Bengaluru with their young children having lost their automotive shop in the Ahmedabad earthquake of 2001. Facing financial difficulty, a chance encounter with a visiting relative at an exhibition who was looking for food to be catered led to the couple setting up a home-cooked meal enterprise. A family-run operation, they would shop, cook and deliver the food themselves, with their children lending a hand with the chores too.  However, work from home and the current situation bought their livelihood to a standstill yet again! Not one to give up though, this family has set-up a small one-table eatery in the east Bengaluru neighbourhood of Kaggadasapura, primarily to serve as a takeaway point for their delicious home-cooked Rajasthani fare, both vegetarian and non-vegetarian. I drive here to chat with the couple, watch them cook a laal maas, sev tamatar and other dishes, before tucking into a delicious meal coupled with the warm hospitality of this Rajput family that has an inspiring, never-give-up attitude. Hope you enjoy this episode, stay safe and happy eating!       

Tandoori Chicken Tangdi
Not cooked in a tandoor, but deep-fried and then fire-cooked with some ghee and spices, the chicken legs, marinated for hours in a spice mix, make for a juicy, char-smoked appetiser.
Rs. 120 (usd 1.6) for 2 pieces.
8/10

Lahsuni Bhindi Fry
Cooked with plenty of browned garlic, green chillies, this is a flavourful, though slightly spicy bhindi fry. 
Rs. 90 (usd 1.2)
7.5/10

Sev Tamatar
Spicy sev (chickpea fritters) are cooked in a tangy, thick tomato gravy that tones down the heat of the sev. The sev garnish also adds an element of crunch and spiciness to this simple but tasty preparation.
Rs. 90 (usd 1.2)
8/10

Besan Gatta
Spiced chickpea dumplings boiled and then cooked in a creamy, mild and slightly tangy, yoghurt based gravy, this is a traditional Rajasthani vegetable delicacy. Rs. 100 (usd 1.4)
8.5/10

Malai Chicken
Chicken, slow cooked with spices in milk that eventually thickens to cream (malai) and hence its name. The thick gravy is fortified with cashew nut paste, and smoked just before serving, adding to the richness and depth of flavour of this delicious chicken gravy
Rs. 170 (usd 2.3)
9/10

Rathodi Chicken Curry
A simple everyday sort of chicken curry. You can taste the coriander and the sweet aroma of the whole spices that have flavoured the curry. 
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2)
8/10

Junglee Maas
A derivative of the Laal Maas cooking process, the meat is removed before the stock is added to make the gravy. The meat is rich in the near caramelised sweetness of the onions, the warming heat of the mathania chillies and the aromatic spices that linger on the palate. 
Rs. 220 (usd 3)
10/10

Laal Maas
Similar in flavours to the junglee maas but fortified with meat stock, this curry may get its colour from the Mathania chilli, but it is quite gentle in the manner in which it greets your palate. 
Rs. 220 (usd 3)
9.5/10

Kheer
Rs. 70 (usd 0.9)
8.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 1pm to 1030pm
Note: Most of the dishes here are prepared fresh to order, so it is advisable to call at least half an hour to an hour ahead and order to minimise wait time. The family is running the show themselves without any assistance at this point; please be patient. Thank you.
ADDRESS -  Swad - n - Swad, No 1/108, RKR Complex Kaggadasapura main road, opposite 16th Cross, Kaggadasapura, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560093; tel: +91 95352 79210/ 74116 97935

title: GOPALJEE CAFÉ | She Quit Her Job To Bring Authentic DELHI Style CHOLE BHATURE To BENGALURU!
description:
#vegetarian #northindianfood #bangalore

gopaljee cafe, delhi chole bhature, delhi style food, north indian, vegetarian, paneer bhaturey, chole, suvigya bansal, passion enterprise, inspiring story

Corporate executive Suvigya Bansal and her entrepreneur husband would scour Bengaluru in search of an authentic Delhi-style chole bhature. When they found none, she decided to quit her job and set up a small eatery that would endeavour to dish out the flavours of their favourite chola bhatura from Delhi. And so seasoned cooks were hired from Delhi, a complex 58-spice masala developed to ensure authenticity of taste, the right size of chickpea sourced to convey the flavour of the spices, et al. Barely had this enterprise found its feet early last year when covid struck! I made a surprise visit to Gopaljee Café one afternoon in response to a plea from the eatery. Suffice to say my conversation with this passionate lady entrepreneur and tasting of the puffy bhature and ‘mazedaar’ chole compelled us to return to film an episode of Gourmet On The Road. Hope you enjoy this one, enough to pay them a visit if possible. Stay safe and happy eating!  

Chole Bhature
The bhatura is light and puffy yet with a bit of strength, to match the tenacity of the 56-spice blend masala that is delicately warming yet has enough depth to linger on the palate. The chickpeas, cocooned in the flavour of the masala, a seasoning of oil, chilli and spices, are stained deep brown by some amla and cooked such that they retain their shape yet yield in a creamy texture to the bite. The mandatory topping of dry, spiced aloo (potatoes) adds a slightly tangy flavour to the dish. If you like it spicy, go for generous bites of the green chilli pickle in between mouthfuls of the chole bhature. If you like paneer, opt for the paneer chole bhature, which arrives with a paneer and coriander mince, stuffed into the bhaturas, and also atop the chole.
Rs. 100 (usd 1.4) per plate, plain 
Rs. 125 (usd 1.7) per plate, with paneer
9/10

Lassi
The lassi is thick and creamy, garnished with nuts, and also provides cooling respite if you have ingested more of the green chilli than you can handle.
Rs. 50 (usd 0.7) 
8/10

Gulab Jamun
The way to end your meal if you have a sweet tooth is with their perfectly browned gulab jamuns.
Rs. 60 (usd 0.8) for two pieces
8/10 

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 9am to 9pm
Note: The chole bhature are served between 9am and 830pm; the bhaturas are fried fresh upon order, so it may involve a bit of a wait especially if crowded.
ADDRESS -  Gopaljee Café, 17/1,chandra mansion, Marathahalli - Sarjapur Rd, Bellandur, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560102; tel: +91 90350 03283/ 91081 71715
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/9DLhEGH91svQpPWc6

title: JAGLI TINDI | This Couple Is Reviving Traditional DAKSHINA KANNADA TIFFIN After Giving Up MNC Jobs!
description:
#vegetarian #tiffin #bangalore

traditional vegetarian snacks from south canara, mangalore, kundapura in bengaluru, jagli tindi, jagli masala dosa, kotte kadubu, kolkatte, banana kesari bath, mandakki upakari, inspiring stories, couple goals, banashankari, south bengaluru 

An engineer and mba by education respectively, Raksha Prasad and Suhas Karanth began making plans to open an eatery that would serve traditional vegetarian tiffin of their native South Canara, during their courting days. Shortly after getting married, they gave up their MNC jobs and their eatery, Jagli Tindi was born, in a tiny nook in Kengeri, on the outskirts of Bengaluru, with a menu comprising mostly dishes gleaned from their grandma’s recipes, with ingredients sourced from Kundapura to lend authenticity to the taste. Two years on, this passion enterprise has moved to a slightly larger space in Banashankari, South Bengaluru, but the couple still remain hands-on, Suhas, in the kitchen, and Raksha managing the front of the house. I visit them to learn of their inspiring story, catch some of the action in the kitchen, before sitting down to a slightly indulgent tiffin session. Hope you enjoy this episode. Stay safe and happy eating!
 
Mandakki Upakari
Made with a red puffed rice that’s tossed with their ‘secret’ podi mix and onions, topped with grated coconut and plenty of peanuts. This is the sort of fun snack that one should share with friends whilst you wait for some of the other substantial tiffin items.
Rs. 30 (usd 0.4)
8/10

Kotte Kadubu 
The kotte kadubu here is made the traditional way, steamed in cups fashioned of jackfruit leaves that lends the kadubu a distinct aroma. There’s a hint of tartness from the fermentation, the red tomato chutney makes for a sprightly partner to the gentle flavoured kadubu, with its tangy, slightly spice, sour and nutty character. The vegetable sagu adds to the nutritional quotient of this tasty tiffin.
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
9/10

Jagli Masala Dosa
This creation of Suhas Karanth seems to be inspired by the 99-variety dosa ilk. The dosa is smeared with a paste of potatoes, spicy podi and ghee, as it is roasted to a crisp on the tava. Folded, flattened and cut into two, this dosa creation makes for an interesting snack if you are the sort who is acquiesce to pushing the envelope for what a masala dosa can be.   
Rs. 58 (usd 0.8)
8.5/10

Kolkatte
Steamed in a banana leaf, this steamed dumpling of urad dal batter, is stained lightly with the colour of the leaf. Slightly pasty and dense in its texture, and studded with whole peppercorns that lend their tingling touch. Whilst the red chutney adds zing, next time, I would also ask for some of the nutritious vegetable saagu to complement the austerity of this steamed dumpling.
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
8.5/10

Banana Kesari Bath
The ripe banana heroes this velvety-textured dish from the start to finish, definitely order a plate of this to close your tindi experience here.
Rs. 25 (usd 0.3)
9/10

Coffee
Rs. 10 (usd 0.1)
8/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 7am to 9pm
Note: This is a relatively young enterprise, please support them with your patience in case of a delay because of the response from this video. Thank you.

title: Best HOMESTYLE GOWDA Lunch at Hassan’s Popular MAMATHA HOTEL | Ragi Mudde, Mutton Korma, Katla Fry
description:
#gowdacuisine #lunch #hassan

popular hassan restaurant, hotel mamatha, gowda food, katla fish fry, mutton biryani, mutton korma, ragi mudde, chicken fry, leg piece, gowda cuisine, naati cuisine, hassan food, mangalore hassan bangalore highway

I often find that the most memorable meals are usually those that happen rather unexpectedly. Like this delicious lunch that we savoured at  this popular eatery in Hassan, 210 kms from Bengaluru, a couple of months ago. Guided by suggestions from our viewers, I didn't quite know what to expect when I walked into a bustling lunch session here late one afternoon on our way back from Mangalore. But the memory of the rustic, homestyle Gowda dishes that I tasted here, lingers to this day. Suffice to say I would happily make the 210 km drive to Mamatha Hotel in a heartbeat just to savour the food all over again. Hope you enjoy the episode. I take this opportunity to wish you and your family a fabulous 2021. Take care and stay safe.

Katla Fry
Coated in a delicious spiced batter that complements the earth flavours of the freshwater fish, the katla fry is a popular dish here for all the right reasons. The crispened skin and the masala work well to cradle the fleshy fish.
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2) for 2 pieces
9/10

Mutton Korma
Notwithstanding bits of fat ribboned through it, the juicy chunks of meat have a bit of a bite. And as you chew on it, you are rewarded with the robust flavours of the curry. This is the sort of delicious mutton curry you would taste in a Gowda home in the area. Makes for a great accompaniment to the ragi mudde and steamed rice.
Rs. 170 (usd 2.3) 
9/10

Mutton Biryani
Flecks of fat abound in this biryani, that is redolent with the aroma of mint and coriander, and do well to coat the zesty, hard-spice laced rice with its unctuousness. The meat is mild in its flavour and benefits from being combined with the rice.
Rs. 210 (usd 2.9)
7.5/10

Chicken Leg Piece
The chicken is tender and juicy, the masala has penetrated deep into the meat that is cooked through to the bone. The spicy batter that crumbs the chicken has depth of flavour that is quite endearing.
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9) for 2 pieces 
9/10

Chicken Fry
The chicken pieces, in a slightly thick gravy, have bits of skin clinging to it.  
Rs. 140 (usd 1.9)
7/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 1230pm to 10pm
Note: Sundays, 1230pm to 5pm; opt to sit upstairs, it is less crowded.
ADDRESS -  Mamatha Hotel, Bangalore - Mangalore Rd, Beside Bhanu Theater, Karigowda Colony, Rangoli Halla, Hassan, Karnataka 573201; tel: +91 72599 23131
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/CR8dUgVM52ETGYgA8

title: 90-Year SHIVAJI MILITARY HOTEL, Bangalore’s Most Popular DONNE BIRYANI Opens Dine-In After 8 Months!
description:
#donnebiryani #lunch #bengaluru

popular biryani restaurant, donne biryani, shivaji military hotel, popular biryani, mutton biryani, chicken biryani, mutton dry, chilli chicken, kaal soup, mutton liver, jayanagar, banashankari, bangalore, bengaluru

When Bengaluru emerged from lockdown months ago, Lokesh and Rajiv, the brothers behind Shivaji Military Hotel took a conscious decision to not reopen dine-in until the situation got better. This meant foregoing a substantial chunk of revenues and relying on takeaway business only, but this was something they were prepared to live with, for the safety of their customers and staff. So when they reopened the eatery to customers a couple of weeks ago, we lost no time in getting there to savour their hugely popular donne biryani and also report on the current experience at this 90-year old culinary institution that has a reputation for being jam packed with customers. We arrived to find certain measures in place, even though in precarious danger of being overrun by its patrons. Thankfully though, the taste of the donne biryani hasn't wavered a bit from the time we tasted it last nearly a year ago. Hope you enjoy this episode, stay safe and happy eating!

Kaal Soup
A warming, gently-spiced mutton bone broth, the trotters are cleaned well and cooked to melt-in-the-mouth texture.
Rs. 180 (usd 2.4)
8.5/10

Chicken Donne Biryani
The biryani is served steaming hot and is impressionable in its persistent aroma and spicy, flavourful fervour laced with green chilli heat. We tasted the donne biryani in takeaway mode where it is packed in foil, but it's not quite the same as when it is ladled onto a donne, a container fashioned of leaves. 
Rs. 200 (usd 2.7)
9/10

Mutton Donne Biryani
The biryani has a slightly smokey tone, and the spices imbued with the weight of the fat and the character of the meat, is rounded in its flavour as opposed to the chicken biryani. The meat is juicy and has absorbed the flavour of the masala rather well. This is the textbook donne biryani, served by this revered culinary institution for the last nine decades. 
Rs. 260 (usd 3.5)
10/10

Chilli Chicken
The chicken is moist, bathed in a green chilli gravy, this is certainly not a dish for the faint-hearted. 
Rs. 180 (2.4)
8.5/10

Mutton Pepper Dry
Tender meat braised in a deep roasted masala with plenty of pepper. 
Rs. 230 (usd 3.1)
9/10

Mutton Liver Fry
The liver has a bit of a bite, its deep flavours juxtapose delightfully against the contrasting freshness of coriander and mint in the green masala.
Rs. 160 (usd 2.2)
8.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: 10am to 4pm
Note: please call ahead to verify timings and dish availability on account of the current situation; closed on Mondays.  
ADDRESS -  Shivaji Military Hotel, No. 718, 1st C Main, 45th Cross, 8th Block, Jayanagar, Bangalore 560 082; tel: +91 98451 49217
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/mZqgz8ZNB4C8e5s38

title: Flavours of East Godavari At KAKINADA SUBBAIAH GARI HOTEL Bangalore | 30-Dish Vegetarian Andhra Meal
description:
#vegetarian #lunch #subbayyagarihotel

popular andhra restaurant, new restaurant, andhra food, subbayya gari hotel, subbaiah gari hotel kakinada, east godavari, kakinada cuisine, andhra sweets, subbaiah hotel hyderabad, subbaiah hotel, banana leaf meal, special lunch, andhra bhojanam, brookefield, whitefield, bangalore, bengaluru

In the year 1950, Subbayya Gaaru opened a small 10-seater mess in Kakinada in the East Godavari region of Andhra Pradesh to serve honestly-priced food of the land. Legend has it that he would treat each customer as a guest visiting his home and leave no stone unturned in feeding them. Tales of his legendary hospitality and traditional fare soon spread far and wide and this tiny eatery evolved into the legendary Subbaiah Gari chain of restaurants. I visit their newly opened Bengaluru outpost where I explore the kitchen and the making of some special dishes before savouring a lavish 30-item banana leaf meal that is served with dollops of neyi (ghee) and old-fashioned hospitality that can leave you bursting at the seams! I also brush up on some Telugu along the way. ;-)  Hope you enjoy this episode, take care and stay safe. Happy eating! 

Special Vegetarian Meal
If you’re looking to savour the traditional flavours of the North Godavari region in Andhra Pradesh, look no further than this special 30-dish Andhra Bhojanam. You begin with tantalising sweets like annavaram prasadam, poornam boorelu, junnu, savoury fries like the tamalapaku (betel leaf) bajji, garelu, before moving on to the procession of curries, lentils, tantalising rice preparations like the pullihora (tamarind rice), panasa (raw jackfruit) mukkala biryani and chutneys. The list of dishes served is far too long to be contained within this description, but suffice to say the food prepared by the master cooks who have trained in the original Kakinada Subbayya Gaari Hotel will hold your attention. But then, this is also the sort of meal that you need to savour at leisure, in order to do full justice to the dishes that are served with generous dollops of neyi (ghee) and old-fashioned hospitality. 
Rs. 250 (usd 3.4)
9/10


Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Lunch - 11am to 4pm; Dinner - 7pm to 10pm 
Note: Note: Subbaiah Gari also serves their famous Butta Bhojanam, a takeaway meal bundle that will feed 4 to 6 diners for Rs. 400. Those with a smaller appetite can consider the ‘single meals’ that are priced at Rs. 150 with a limited selection of dishes. Curries are also available at Rs. 50 per portion. 
ADDRESS -  Subbaiah Gari Hotel, 1, ITPL Main Rd, MLayout, Brookefield, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560037; tel: +91 82774 00123
LOCATION TAG - https://goo.gl/maps/nGsLxrfuW4QgLe5W6

title: This New NORTHWEST KEBAB & CURRYHOUSE Serves Tasty Kebabs And Curries Beyond The Usual North Indian!
description:
#bangalore #kebabs #curries

new restaurant, restaurant with a cause, inspiring stories, north west frontier cuisine, kebabs, curries, tandoor, sigri, barbeque, vegetarian, non vegetarian, north indian food, koramangala, bengaluru

In the current climate of gloom and doom, Chefs Sanjay Tyagi and Shyam Sundar Bhaskaran, both seasoned culinary professionals with stints in some top Indian kitchens in the country and overseas, have launched a culinary enterprise to not just serve delicious fare but also, more importantly in our opinion, provide livelihoods to chefs and f&b professionals who have lost their jobs at some of the city’s top hotels. The result is Northwest Kebab & Curryhouse, a breezy casual dining restaurant in Koramangala, that is showcasing an interesting repertoire of dishes from the North West Frontier region. Barely a couple of weeks old, and with not too many customers at present, this is certainly an eatery to pencil into your eating-out plans if you are looking to taste “North Indian-style” of food that goes beyond the ubiquitous palak paneer and butter chicken! Hope you enjoy this episode, take care and stay safe.

Mewe Aur Subz Ki Seekh
A delicately spiced kebab that offers the richness of reduced milk solids, dry fruits and the freshness of vegetables that intermingles with the gentle spice of chillies.
Rs. 289 (usd 3.9)
8/10 

Paneer Parathdar
Marinated paneer, that is soft and creamy to the bite, stuffed with a slightly spicy, tangy paste of sun dried tomatoes. 
Rs. 289 (usd 3.9)
8.5/10 

Teekhi Machli
A dish that is a confluence of the North, in the mustard oil, and the South, toasted curry leaves and tamarind, that go to flavour the masala that the tilapia is tava-fried in. 
Rs. 429 (usd 5.8)
9/10 

Tabak Maaz
Tender lamb that is braised in saffron, spices and milk, and then finished with ghee. At Northwest Kebab & Curry House, the braised meat is then coated in a light batter and fried. The juicy succulence of the fat and the ghee is what one tastes on the palate as the meat peels away from the bone. 
Rs. 439 (usd 6)
9/10

Chicken Behari/ Mutton Behari
A moist and gently flavoured grilled morsel of meat with none of the heavy handed spicing that one would associate with a North Indian Kebab. My vote though goes to the mutton version of this kebab where the tenderiser has imparted a creamy texture to the smokey flavours of the meat.
Rs. 389 (usd 5.3)/ Rs. 439 (usd 6)
8.5/10 / 9.5/10

Bhindi Musallam
Slit and spiced tender ladyfingers that are fried and topped with a rich musallam gravy of almonds and heavy cream, and garnished with beaten silver, rose petals and saffron oil. 
Rs. 289 (usd 3.9)
8/10

Methi Malai Kofta
Paneer and potato dumplings stuffed with prunes and nuts, cooked in a tomato and cream based gravy laced with the slightly bitter edge of fresh fenugreek.  
Rs. 339 (usd 4.6)
8.5/10

Murg Shinwari Karahi
A rustic preparation that one would perhaps encounter on a highway stop in the NorthWest, one tastes the untamed flavours of ginger, green chillies, coriander seeds in this chicken dish that is prepared and served in cast iron karahi
Rs. 429 (usd 5.8)
8.5/10

Nalli Rogan E Nishat
If you are a mutton lover, this is a must-order dish here. The curry bears the lip-smacking goodness of tender meat and bone marrow, the meat the sort that not just slides off the bone but almost melts away when placed in the mouth.
Rs. 499 (usd 6.8)
10/10

Dal Makhni 
Rs. 289 (usd 3.9)
7.5/10

Zaffrani Pulao
Rs. 249 (usd 3.34)
8/10

Husn E Ara
Rs. 129 (1.7)
7.5/10

Samak Ke Chawal Ki Phirni
Rs. 129 (1.7)
9/10

Sheer Kurma
Rs. 129 (1.7)
8.5/10

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Lunch - 12 to 3pm; Dinner - 630 to 1130pm 
Note: Although the team is one with a fair bit of experience, this is a new restaurant trying to find its feet. Please be patient and do call ahead to reserve. 
ADDRESS -  Northwest Kebab & Curryhouse, No 99, 2nd Floor, 5th Cross Rd, 6th Block, Koramangala, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560 095; tel: +91 99801 01971

title: Exploring SATTVIC Cuisine At THE HIGHER TASTE, ISKCON TEMPLE | Food That Satisfies The Soul!
description:
#vegetarian #sattvic #krishnatemple

temple cuisine, sattvic cuisine,  indian food, vegetarian food, krishna temple, iskcon, rajajinagar,  bangalore, bengaluru

Temple food to many isn't about mere nourishment but a blessing from the divine. And when temple fare is presented in a culinary experience that is not only rich in its depth of traditions, but also celebrates diversity to appeal to all humanity, it is elevated to food that truly satisfies the soul. In a first on Gourmet On The Road, I experience the philosophy and flavours of Sattvic cuisine at The Higher Taste, a fine dining restaurant located in the serene environment of ISKCON Temple, Bengaluru. This isn’t a typical episode, but then the experience too isn't! Hope you enjoy this very special presentation, take care and stay safe.

Please note:
As a mark of respect to this meal that is served in a temple complex, I have chosen to not rate the dishes in this episode. Thank you.

Nuggekai Rasam
The rasam is flavourful and aromatic, you can taste the sweet lilt of fennel, the warmth of pepper and the weight of the lentils and drumstick drumstick pulp. The floating drumstick kernels add to the appeal of this nourishing broth.
Rs. 165 (usd 2.2)

Multani Paneer Tikka
The paneer is stuffed with the richness of cream and nuts, marinated in yoghurt, saffron and cooked in the tandoor. The peppers provide for a pleasing crunch, and the chaat masala cuts through the dairy richness and refreshes the palate. 
Rs. 325 (usd 4.4)

Potato Milagu Fry
Baby potatoes that are tossed in a sprightly spice mix, loaded with pepper, chilli flakes, cumin, crunchy, fried curry leaves and the fresh tang of lime juice. 
Rs. 230 (usd 3.1)

Mango Rasgulla Chaat
Visualise a chatpata paapdi chaat where the paapdi is replaced with soft rasgullas immersed in the sweetness of mango pulp. If you want to begin your meal on a sweet and spicy note, this is the dish to try. 
Rs. 250 (usd 3.4)    

Raja Bhojanam
Paneer, peas and nuts cooked in a rich cashew, cream and ghee laden curry, topped with a touch of saffron, this curry is a touch of indulgence befitting a king! The spicing is mellow, barring the tingling prick of heat when one bites into a peppercorn. The soft, layered warki paratha makes for a comforting companion to the Raja Bhojanam. If you’d like to add a touch of spice, savour this gravy with the chilli cheese naan, stuffed with mozzarella that bridges to the creamy flavour of the curry, and topped with finely chopped green chillies.
Rs. 285 (usd 3.9)
Warki Paratha - Rs. 80 (usd 1.1)
Chilli Cheese Naan - Rs. 120 (usd 1.6)

Vazhaipoo Murungakai Kozhambu
A ‘coconutty’ curry with fried banana blossoms and drumstick segments. The drumstick segments are a tad fibrous, the banana blossom, deep-fried, lends a bit of a bite to this dish. The curry is thick, rich in its coconut flavours and does well to smother every grain of the rice.
Rs. 285 (usd 3.9)

Vetrilai Thakkali Satham
An unusual rice preparation that brings together the sharp flavours of betel leaves with tomatoes. Although the paan flavours are quite pronounced on the palate, the pulpy freshness of the fresh tomatoes helps cut the astringency of the former. Rs. 280 (usd 3.8)

Elaneer Payasam
A payasam of tender coconut, coconut milk, thickened milk for sweetening, this payasam makes for a pleasing end to the meal at The Higher Taste.
Rs. 210 (usd 2.9)

Paan Ice Cream
A sweet paan that’s blended into a homemade ice cream, this is a ‘beeda’ the customary sweet paan that concludes a festive meal, in a dessert!
Rs.  165 (usd 2.2)

Please note:
As a mark of respect to this meal that is served in a temple complex, I have chosen to not rate the dishes in this episode. Thank you.

Kripal Amanna,
Gourmet On The Road,
Food Lovers TV

TIMINGS: Lunch - 1130am to 3pm; Dinner - 7pm to 1030pm on all days 
Note: Some of the dishes may be subject to seasonal availability.
ADDRESS -  The Higher Taste, Inside ISKCON, Hare Krishna Hill, Chord Rd, Bengaluru, Karnataka 560010; tel: +91 94494 95440/ +91 802357 5333
